revision.text:
{{see also|Macmillan Publishers (United States)}} {{Infobox publisher | name = Crowell-Collier Publishing Company | image = | parent = | status = defunct (1973) | founded = 1877 | founder = Phineas P. Mast | successor = [[Macmillan Publishers (United States)|Macmillan Company]] | country = U.S. | headquarters = [[Springfield, Ohio]], later [[New York City]] | distribution = National | keypeople = | publications = [[Magazines]], Reference books | topics = | genre = | imprints = | revenue = | numemployees = | nasdaq = | url = | owner = P. P. Mast (1877–1898)
John S. Crowell (1898–1906)
[[Joseph P. Knapp]] and George Hazen (1906–?) }} '''Crowell-Collier Publishing Company''' was an American [[Publishing|publisher]] that owned the popular magazines ''[[Collier's]]'', ''[[Woman's Home Companion]]'' and ''[[The American Magazine]]''. Crowell also published general interest books and references such as ''[[Collier's Encyclopedia]]'' and the [[Harvard Classics]] series of books. The company was founded by agricultural [[Tool and die maker|tool manufacturer]] P. P. Mast with a single magazine, ''[[Farm & Fireside]] (''later [[Farm & Fireside|the ''Country Home'']]'')'' to sell farm tools and implements in 1877 in [[Springfield, Ohio]]. By 1881, Mast had relinquished control to John S. Crowell who expanded their company by purchasing ''Home Companion'' (later changing the name to ''[[Woman's Home Companion]]''). After P. P. Mast's death in 1898, Crowell obtained control of the company and established it as the Crowell Publishing Company. Crowell Publishing expanded their magazine holdings with ''[[The American Magazine]]'' in 1911 and the weekly ''[[Collier's]]'' in 1919. At one point Collier's weekly had over 1.25 million subscribers. Crowell's also published the ''[[Collier's Encyclopedia]]'' which came under fire from the FTC in 1940 for deceptive sales practices. After shuttering the magazine operations in the 1950s, the Crowell-Collier Publishing Company merged with the American [[Macmillan Publishers (United States)|Macmillan Company]] in 1960 and became a large [[Education|educational]] company with subsidiaries for books, textbooks, [[Correspondence school|correspondence schools]] and other educational tools and materials. The company officially changed its name to '''Macmillan, Inc.''' in 1973. == Early History == [[File:US-OH(1891) p685 SPRINGFIELD, P.P. MAST & CO.jpg|thumb|upright|left|P. P. Mast and Company, Springfield, Ohio]] {{multiple image | align = right | direction = vertical | width = 220 | image1 = John-S-Crowell.jpg | alt1 = | caption1 = John S. Crowell | image2 =US-OH(1891) p678 SPRINGFIELD, MAST, CROWELL & KIRKPATRICK.jpg | alt2 = | caption2 = Mast, Crowell and Kirkpatrick Publishers (1891) }} The Crowell-Collier Publishing Company had its roots in the agricultural trade of the 19th century. Industrialist Phineas P. Mast, the owner of P. P. Mast, manufactured farm and agricultural tools, and he wanted a magazine to promote his products.{{Cite web|url=https://clarkcountyhistory.wordpress.com/tag/phineas-p-mast/|title=Phineas P. Mast – clarkcountyhistory|website=clarkcountyhistory.wordpress.com|access-date=2016-04-23|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161012013139/https://clarkcountyhistory.wordpress.com/tag/phineas-p-mast/|archivedate=2016-10-12|df=}} Mast made wind engines, [[pump]]s, [[Plough|plows]] and [[mower]]s in [[Springfield, Ohio]]. Mast hired John S. Crowell away from the successful ''Home and Farm'' of Louisville in 1877 to manage the new bi-monthly farm [[Magazine|journal]] called ''[[Farm & Fireside]]''.{{Cite web|url=http://www.subscriptiontoamerica.org/chronology/chronology.htm|title=Chronology|website=www.subscriptiontoamerica.org|access-date=2016-04-17|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160308203144/http://www.subscriptiontoamerica.org/chronology/chronology.htm|archivedate=2016-03-08|df=}} By the 1890s, ''Farm & Fireside'' maintained a circulation of over half a million.{{Cite book|title=A History of American Magazines, Vol. IV|last=Mott|first=Frank Luther|publisher=Harvard Press|year=1930|isbn=9780674395503|location=Cambridge, MA|pages=337}} Mast relinquished his role as acting executive in 1879, but he stayed on as an investor. Crowell along with T.J. Kirkpatrick (who was Mast's nephew) then changed the name of the publishing house to Mast, Crowell and Kirkpatrick Publishers. The publishers soon expanded from the one magazine into other markets. They constructed the Farm and Fireside building in Springfield, Ohio, in 1881. In 1883, they purchased the ''[[Woman's Home Companion|Home Companion]]'' magazine from a Harvey & Finn of [[Cleveland, Ohio]] to meet the growing demand for content aimed at women.{{Cite book|title=A History of American Magazines, Vol IV|last=Mott|first=Frank Luther|publisher=Harvard Press|year=1957|isbn=978-0674395503|location=|pages=769–772}} They bought ''Youth's Home Library'', a similar paper that had been published in [[Boston]], and merged it with their youth-oriented publication ''Our Young People''. They then changed the name of the three merged periodicals back to the title ''Home Companion'', a general family magazine. By 1890 the magazine's subscription had reached 100,000. The ''Companion'' had a number of names but was changed to ''[[Woman's Home Companion]]'' in 1896. By the 1890s, ''Farm & Fireside'' was also publishing regional editions of the periodical. After the death of P. P. Mast in 1898, the company changed the name to Crowell and Kirkpatrick Publishers. == 20th Century == {{multiple image | align = left | direction = vertical | width = 170 | image1 = Womans Home Companion 1916-04.jpg | alt1 = | caption1 = ''Woman's Home Companion'' for April 1916 | image2 =Jo-Cotten-American-FC-1931.jpg | alt2 = | caption2 = ''The American Magazine'' in 1931 | image3 =Collier's2-2-1924.jpg | alt3 = | caption3 = ''Collier's'' in February 1924 }} As the [[20th century]] began, the company changed hands again and moved into mainstream magazine publishing. P. P. Mast died in 1898 (leaving an estate of a million and a half dollars). In 1902, John S. Crowell obtained Kirkpatrick's interests and established it as the Crowell Publishing Company. In 1906, Crowell turned around and sold his interest in the company to [[Joseph P. Knapp]] and George Hazen of [[New York City|New York]], who incorporated in [[New Jersey]] and kept the name Crowell Publishing Company.{{Cite web|url=http://archives.nypl.org/uploads/collection/pdf_finding_aid/crowellcollier.pdf|title=Crowell-Collier Publishing Company Records, 1931-1955|last=|first=|date=|website=Guide to the Crowell-Collier Publishing Company Records|publisher=The New York Public Library Humanities and Social Sciences Library Manuscripts and Archives Division|access-date=April 23, 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304054941/http://archives.nypl.org/uploads/collection/pdf_finding_aid/crowellcollier.pdf|archivedate=March 4, 2016|df=}} The new company maintained offices in [[New York City]] in addition to [[Springfield, Ohio]].{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1911/02/12/archives/the-iliad-of-homer-the-latest-attempt-to-render-the-greek.html|title=The Iliad of Homer|date=1911-02-12|work=The New York Times|access-date=2018-06-07|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331}} Crowell Publishing Company lost a 1908 appeal before the Board of United States General Appraisers and were assessed [[countervailing duties]] on paper imported from Canada.{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1908/04/01/archives/latest-customs-rulings-countervailing-duty-accrues-on-printing.html|title=LATEST CUSTOMS RULINGS.; Countervailing Duty Accrues on Printing Paper -- Other Tariff Decisions.|date=1908-04-01|work=The New York Times|access-date=2018-06-07|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331}} === 1910s and Acquisition of Major Periodicals === {{see also|Collier's}} Crowell Publishing acquired ''[[The American Magazine]]'' in 1911 from the Phillips Publishing Company.{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1911/02/02/archives/elevated-agents-robbed-lone-highwayman-holds-up-two-station-gets.html|title=ELEVATED AGENTS ROBBED.; Lone Highwayman Holds Up Two Station -- Gets All Receipts In one.|date=1911-02-02|work=The New York Times|access-date=2018-06-08|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331}} The magazine had [[Muckraker|muckraking]] roots but with the decline of muckraking journalism it had turned into a general interest magazine. However, an article in [[the New York Times]] noted that "the purchase of ''the American Magazine'' by Crowell Publishing Company meant that 'the interests' were bent on swallowing up the muckrakers..."{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1911/02/05/archives/partner-of-morgan-in-magazine-firm-thomas-w-lamont-one-of-the-new.html|title=PARTNER OF MORGAN IN MAGAZINE FIRM; Thomas W. Lamont One of the New Owners of the American Magazine.|date=1911-02-05|work=The New York Times|access-date=2018-06-08|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331}} They pointed to the fact that one of the heavy stockholders in the Crowell firm was [[Thomas W. Lamont]] who was also a partner of the newly formed [[J.P. Morgan & Co.|J. P. Morgan & Company]]. [[Cleveland Moffett]], a known muckraking journalist was quoted, "...we are up against the powers of darkness. The right of free speech in America is in jeopardy. They are trying to muzzle the magazines. Several magazines have changed hands recently. They have come under the control of interests, and in each of them the muckraking features will cease. Muckraking, in spite of its name, is a power in this country, standing as it does to promote good citizenship." However, a second ''New York Times'' article about the acquisition stated that writers such as [[Ida Tarbell]], Peter F. Dunne, and [[William Allen White]] were pleased with the opportunity. A spokesman from Phillips said that "...instead of reaching 300,000 readers, we can now reach 3,000,000 readers through our new allies in the publication field. We ourselves were afraid the Trusts were behind the proposition before we looked into it, but all the magazines we affiliate with are insurgent like ourselves, and controlled by persons of insurgent sympathies." That same year, several magazine publishers including Crowell were accused of conspiring to keep up magazine prices through the Periodical Clearing House. According to John Wood, a magazine man whose business had been severely impacted, the Periodical Clearing House was organized by law clerks and employees of the magazines.{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1911/06/25/archives/accuses-magazines-of-trade-restraint-club-rate-agent-says-the.html|title=ACCUSES MAGAZINES OF TRADE RESTRAINT; Club Rate Agent Says the Leading Publishers Are in a Conspiracy to Keep Up Prices.|date=1911-06-25|work=The New York Times|access-date=2018-06-07|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331}} Wood claimed that ruinous fines had impacted his ability to sell subscriptions. At the same time libraries in the Central Western and Western states complained that the clearing house caused the cessation of club rates on magazines to libraries. In 1919, the Crowell Publishing Company bought another general interest magazine, ''[[Collier's]]: The National Weekly'', and assumed control of Collier's book publishing.{{Cite web|url=http://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1919/07/26/issue.html|title=The New York Times: Saturday July 26, 1919|website=timesmachine.nytimes.com|access-date=2016-04-17}} ''Collier's'' also had roots in muckraking journalism and social reform and had one of the largest magazine subscription audiences, then around one million weekly. The book-publishing arm published popular and serious literature topics as well as the ''[[Collier's Encyclopedia]]'' and published six million copies a year of books.{{multiple image | align = right | direction = vertical | width = 220 | image1 = Crowell-Collier Publishing Co., Springfield, Ohio. LOC gsc.5a19391.jpg | alt1 = | caption1 = Press room at the Crowell-Collier Publishing Company in Springfield, Ohio (1949) | image2 = Crowell-Collier Publishing Co., Springfield, Ohio. LOC gsc.5a19392.jpg | alt2 = | caption2 = Proofing machine at the Crowell-Collier Publishing Company in Springfield, Ohio (1949) }} === 1920s === By 1924, the weekly circulation of ''Collier's'' had grown to 1,250,000. Crowell moved its print operations to Springfield, Ohio, because of "excessive postage involved in mailing from a seaboard city under wartime postal rates".{{Cite web|url=http://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1924/05/27/119039162.html?pageNumber=5|title=COLLIER'S PLANT TO MOVE TO OHIO; Publication Follows Others That Have Left New York Because of Union Conditions. POSTAGE ALSO AN ITEM To Be Printed Under "Open Shop" Regulations at Springfield -- Bernarr-McFadden May Go.|website=timesmachine.nytimes.com|access-date=2016-04-17}} The editorial and business departments remained in New York. === 1930s === In 1930 ''Farm & Fireside'' magazine changed its name to ''The Country Home''. Also in 1930, the Crowell Publishing Company and P. F. Collier and Sons were sued for libel by R.B. Creager, a Republican National Committeeman for Texas. Creager sought $500,000 in damages after an article titled "High-Handed and Hell-Bent" appeared in ''Collier's Weekly''. The article by Owen P. White covered a political situation on the Mexican border in Hidalgo County. The jury returned a verdict for Crowell Publishing.{{Cite web|url=http://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1930/05/16/96123460.html?pageNumber=22|title=CREAGER LOSES SUIT AGAINST COLLIER'S; Republican Leader in Texas Sought $500,000 Damages for Story in Magazine.|website=timesmachine.nytimes.com|access-date=2016-04-17}} In 1939, Crowell Publishing merged the New York operations and changed the company name to The Crowell-Collier Publishing Co.{{Cite web|url=http://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1939/06/02/93923277.html?pageNumber=38|title=Advertising News and Notes; Newspaper Campaigns Listed|website=timesmachine.nytimes.com|access-date=2016-04-19}} That same year, ''The Country Home'' was discontinued.{{Cite web|url=http://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1939/10/25/94729787.html?pageNumber=29|title=Magazine Will Suspend|website=timesmachine.nytimes.com|access-date=2016-04-18}}{{Cite web|url=http://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1939/10/25/94729996.html?pageNumber=39|title=Advertising News and Notes; Drake's Cake in Newspapers|website=timesmachine.nytimes.com|access-date=2016-04-19}} === 1940s === In 1940 the [[FTC Fair Information Practice|FTC]] investigated the sales methods used for the ''Collier's Encyclopedia''. The publishing company and its officers and directors of the corporations were charged with misleading sale methods and representations in the sale of books and encyclopedias. The complaint charged that "contrary to claims made, none of the respondents' publications is ever given as the result of a drawing or free, and as a gift or gratuity; that the purchase price of so-called free goods is, in every instance, included in the price of other merchandise sold to the customer; that in no case do they sell at actual cost, that the sum of $59 represented as a reduced price is the regular price, and that other claims are 'also deceptive and misleading.'"{{Cite web|url=http://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1940/11/12/94012745.html?pageNumber=40|title=CROWELL CITED BY FTC; Complaint Charges Book Sales Methods Were Misleading|website=timesmachine.nytimes.com|access-date=2016-04-18}} During [[World War II]], Crowell-Collier sponsored publication of a magazine for servicemen called ''Victory''.{{Cite web|url=http://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1943/02/19/85084679.html?pageNumber=38|title=COPIES OF 'VICTORY' SENT TO SOLDIERS; OWI Office Letter Obtained by Senators Gives Details of Budget and Plans ADVERTISING EXPLAINED Success of 'Signal,' German Propaganda Organ, Caused Agency's Counter-Attack|website=timesmachine.nytimes.com|access-date=2016-04-19}} In 1946, the Vanderbilt mansion at Fifth Avenue and Fifty-First Street was slated to be razed and replaced with a 19-story office building for the Crowell-Collier Publishing Company.{{Cite web|url=http://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1946/12/01/88384960.html?pageNumber=206|title=Passing of the Marble Front|website=timesmachine.nytimes.com|access-date=2016-04-19}} === 1950s financial reverses === [[File:Crowell-Collier-Springfield-OH.jpg|thumb|Crowell-Collier building in Springfield, Ohio (2011)]] In the mid-1950s, Crowell-Collier had heavy deficits and discontinued ''The American Magazine'', ''Collier's'', and ''Woman's Home Companion''. In December 1956 the company closed its Springfield plant, which at one point had employed more than 2,000 people. The closing shocked both publishers and readers.{{Cite web|url=http://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1962/06/17/issue.html|title=The New York Times: Sunday June 17, 1962|website=timesmachine.nytimes.com|access-date=2016-04-23}} Many in the magazine field deemed the closing "a foolish and impetuous move",{{Cite web|url=http://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1962/06/17/89862835.html?pageNumber=120|title=Advertising: Books and Magazines Merging; Publishing Trend Is Shown by Recent Developments. Impact on Finance Editorial Content Is Fundamental Latest in a Series Line Discontinued Other Reports Another Venture|website=timesmachine.nytimes.com|access-date=2016-04-23}} but as the company moved to reinvent itself as a producer of books and educational materials, the move was seen as shrewd and far-visioned. === 1960s and reinvention as educational publisher === By the early 1960s, Crowell-Collier had recovered financially. Leaving behind its roots in magazine publishing, it now turned to the growing market for education produced by the [[baby boom]] in the United States. Book sales had surged for [[Reference work|reference books]], [[Textbook|textbooks]], and [[Encyclopedia|encyclopedias]] and like many of the large publishers of that era such as [[Random House]] and [[Simon & Schuster]], Crowell-Collier embarked on a [[Mergers and acquisitions|merger and acquisitions]] spree. Crowell-Collier kicked off the decade by merging with the American [[Macmillan Publishers (United States)|Macmillan]] company and moved into the educational space. This was then followed by a number of mergers and acquisitions.{{Cite web|url=http://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1961/12/20/issue.html|title=The New York Times: Wednesday December 20, 1961|website=timesmachine.nytimes.com|access-date=2016-04-20}} On the move into education, Chairman Raymond C. Hagel said, "We envision our major role as that of a developer of complete educational systems." He explained that an educational system was a "unified instructional package involving a variety of tools." and that "the business of education has become a successor to the defense industry. It is a security lifeline."{{Cite web|url=http://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1965/05/16/104229994.html?pageNumber=187|title=Personality: Diversifier in Publishing Field; Crowell Collier Head Sets a 'Pattern for Future'|website=timesmachine.nytimes.com|access-date=2016-04-21}} Crowell would end the decade as Crowell Collier & Macmillan, a large conglomeration of subsidiaries that included books, schools, magazines, educational tools, bookstores, [[Book sales club|book club]]s and radio stations and with an annual revenue of $390 million.{{Cite web|url=http://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1970/02/11/76699111.html?pageNumber=90|title=Goodyear Rubber and R.J. Reynolds Profits Rise|website=timesmachine.nytimes.com|access-date=2016-04-24}} === Merger with Macmillan === {{see also|Macmillan Publishers (United States)}} In December 1959, Crowell-Collier acquired 29 percent of [[Macmillan Publishers (United States)|Macmillian Company]]{{Cite web|url=http://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1960/04/17/99732332.html?pageNumber=76|title=RECENT MERGERS ALTER BOOK FIELD; Holt and 2 Other Concerns Exchanging Stock -- Text House Also in Deal|date=April 17, 1960|website=[[The New York Times]]|access-date=2016-04-21}}{{Cite web|url=http://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1960/08/04/99508342.html?pageNumber=35|title=CROWELL-COLLIER |date=August 4, 1960|website=[The New York Times|access-date=2016-04-20}} which published [[fiction]], [[non-fiction]], [[textbook]]s, [[Reference work|reference books]], religious books and [[children's books]].{{Cite web|url=http://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1960/12/16/99979696.html?pageNumber=53|title=MERGER IS VOTED FOR PUBLISHERS; Stockholders of Macmillan and Crowell-Collier Back Exchange of Shares|website=timesmachine.nytimes.com|access-date=2016-04-20}} By August 1960, Crowell-Collier held a 52.8 percent interest in Macmillan, and on December 30, 1960, the companies merged.{{cite web|url=http://archives.nypl.org/mss/703#overview|title=Crowell-Collier Publishing Company records 1931–1955|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=[[New York Public Library]]|access-date=2017-07-03|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160822153253/http://archives.nypl.org/mss/703#overview|archivedate=2016-08-22|df=}} Macmillan was once the American division of the [[Macmillan Publishers|British Macmillan]] Publishers (opened in 1869) and had been run by generations of the Brett family who eventually bought the company from the British in 1896. Macmillan published some notable authors including [[Jack London]], [[Margaret Mitchell]], and [[Winston Churchill]]. At the time, the majority of Macmillan's sales came from textbooks{{Cite web|url=http://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1960/07/31/99767673.html?pageNumber=114|title=Publishers of Books Are Turning to Mergers; Some Stocks Listed and Advertising Drives Pushed BOOK PUBLISHING IS TURNING A LEAF|website=timesmachine.nytimes.com|access-date=2016-04-22}}{{Cite web|url=http://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1960/12/16/99979696.html?pageNumber=53|title=MERGER IS VOTED FOR PUBLISHERS; Stockholders of Macmillan and Crowell-Collier Back Exchange of Shares|website=timesmachine.nytimes.com|access-date=2016-04-21}}{{Cite web|url=http://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1968/03/04/77078525.html?pageNumber=28|title=Book Trade Upset by Changes in Ownership, Size and Staff|website=timesmachine.nytimes.com|access-date=2016-04-24}} and for Macmillan the merger meant access to cash and capital to grow their textbook market. Crowell-Collier ran Macmillan as a subsidiary but in 1965 Crowell-Collier officially changed its name to Crowell Collier & Macmillan, Inc.{{Cite web|url=http://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1965/05/05/101544765.html?pageNumber=64|title=Advertising: New Name and Emblem at Cities Service|website=timesmachine.nytimes.com|access-date=2016-04-20}} Publishing was dropped from the company name to reflect its broadened scope into education.{{Cite web|url=http://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1965/05/05/issue.html|title=The New York Times: Wednesday May 5, 1965|website=timesmachine.nytimes.com|access-date=2016-04-21}} === Encyclopedias, books and educational materials === Textbooks and encyclopedias were a booming business in 1959. While general books accounted for $408 million in sales, textbooks and encyclopedias totaled $597 million. Crowell's subsidiary P. F. Collier and Sons published the ''[[Collier's Encyclopedia]]'' and released a new 24-volume set in 1962.{{Cite web|url=http://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1962/04/24/82124946.html?pageNumber=49|title=CROWELL-COLLIER MAPS ACQUISITION; Purchase of an Educational Magazine Is Slated|website=timesmachine.nytimes.com|access-date=2016-04-24}} Since 1909 it also published the 51-volume [[Harvard Classics]], an anthology of classic and world literature. The company expanded the line of encyclopedias by announcing that it would use the resources of Crowell-Collier, Macmillian and Free Press to begin work on a new multi-volume set on [[social science]]s.{{Cite web|url=http://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1960/12/16/99979448.html?pageNumber=30|title=ENCYCLOPEDIA SET ON SOCIAL SCIENCE; 3 Publishers Join in Venture Called First of Its Kind in More Than 25 Years|website=timesmachine.nytimes.com|access-date=2016-04-22}} W. Allen Wallis, named chairman of the editorial board for the encyclopedia said, "In the past few years we have stressed the physical sciences because of our concern for defense, and the biological sciences because of our interest in better health. Perhaps of even greater importance to the continued survival of our country and, therefore, the whole free world, will be our ability to solve some of the great social problems of the day." [[File:UBN Collier's Encyclopedia.JPG|thumb|UBN Collier's Encyclopedia]] The [[Federal Trade Commission]] again cited Crowell-Collier and subsidiary P. F. Collier and Sons with making false claims through the door-to-door salesmen of the encyclopedias.{{Cite web|url=http://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1960/02/01/99340169.html?pageNumber=38|title=F.T.C. CITES PUBLISHER; Crowell-Collier Accused of Making False Claims|website=timesmachine.nytimes.com|access-date=2016-04-21}} In an article on stockholder questions in ''[[The New York Times]]'', shareholders at a meeting in 1963 complained about tactics used by door-to-door encyclopedia salesmen.{{Cite web|url=http://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1963/04/28/356693802.html?pageNumber=168|title=MEETINGS DRAW MORE QUESTIONS; Shareholders Are Eager bdt Queries Often Odd|website=timesmachine.nytimes.com|access-date=2016-04-23}} Nine years later in 1969, the F.T.C. ordered the distributors of Collier's Encyclopedias to stop the use of deceptive sales promoting the publication. The agency charged the company with "Implying through promotional literature and door-to-door salesmen that a set of the encyclopedias would be given free or at a reduced price if yearly supplements were purchased."{{Cite web|url=http://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1969/02/27/77445371.html?pageNumber=19|title=F.T.C. Tells Colliers to Halt Encyclopedia Sales Tactics|website=timesmachine.nytimes.com|access-date=2016-04-24}} In 1960, Crowell began to expand further into general book markets. Collier Books, the paperback division of Crowell-Collier Publishing Company, began publishing in October 1961 at the rate of 50 paperback titles a month.{{Cite web|url=http://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1962/07/24/80419714.html?pageNumber=18|title=Crowell-Collier to Publish 24 Books in New Series|website=timesmachine.nytimes.com|access-date=2016-04-20}}{{Cite web|url=http://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1961/06/21/101467452.html?pageNumber=54|title=Crowell-Collier Plans Paper Back Editions|website=timesmachine.nytimes.com|access-date=2016-04-21}} The list included scholarly books, nonfiction and fiction reprints and original works.{{Cite web|url=http://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1961/07/02/issue.html|title=The New York Times: Sunday July 2, 1961|website=timesmachine.nytimes.com|access-date=2016-04-22}} Crowell-Collier Press was a hardcover publisher started in 1962 with a focus on adult nonfiction and children's books. The children's series, the Modern Masters Books for Children, was edited by anthologist [[Louis Untermeyer]] and included picture books by [[Robert Graves]] (''The Big Green Book''), [[Shirley Jackson]] (''9 Magic Wishes'') and [[Phyllis McGinley]] (''The B Book'').{{Cite web|url=http://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1962/11/11/109373872.html?pageNumber=366|title=Beginners: Easy Reading|website=timesmachine.nytimes.com|access-date=2016-04-23}} The books were created using a controlled vocabulary of fewer than 800 words created by elementary educators.{{Cite web|url=http://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1962/10/31/90577328.html?pageNumber=58|title=Series of Books Uses 800 Words For a Beginner|website=timesmachine.nytimes.com|access-date=2016-04-23}} In 1962, Crowell also purchased book club distributor Scientific Materials, Inc., which included Library of Science, Science Book Club, Natural History Book Club, and Basic Book Service. In addition to the four professional level book clubs, two others aimed at young adults including the Young Adults' Division and Junior Scientists Division of the Library of Science were also a part of the acquisition. Crowell-Collier later that same year turned around and sold the toy manufacturing arm of Scientific Materials, Inc. to Allis-Chalmers manufacturing{{Cite web|url=http://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1962/05/08/106219789.html?pageNumber=60|title=CROWELL-COLLIER MAPS ACQUISITION; Purchase of Operator of Six Book Clubs Is Slated|website=timesmachine.nytimes.com|access-date=2016-04-21}}{{Cite web|url=http://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1962/11/09/issue.html|title=The New York Times: Friday November 9, 1962|website=timesmachine.nytimes.com|access-date=2016-04-23}} In 1962, Crowell made another push into the book market with a purchase of book clubs and retail bookstores. In the same year, they purchased 16 [[Brentano's]] bookstores. At the time bookstores were heavily competing with [[Department store|department stores]] and discount houses offering reduced rates for bestsellers.{{Cite web|url=http://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1962/04/05/96965052.html?pageNumber=35|title=Crowell-Collier Buys Brentano's And Will Run It as Subsidiary; Brentano's, Dealers in Books--Leather-Bound to Paper-Backed|website=timesmachine.nytimes.com|access-date=2016-04-21}} By 1967, the Brentano's chain had grown to 21 stores and had sales of $7 million.{{Cite web|url=http://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1967/06/10/90358697.html?pageNumber=30|title=RISE IN BOOKSHOPS NOTED AT PARLEY; Trade Is Called Country's 'Most Underdeveloped'|website=timesmachine.nytimes.com|access-date=2016-04-23}} In 1962, Crowell-Collier Publishing Company created a new division called Crowell-Collier Educational Corporation. The educational arm was created to develop instructional and reference materials as well as teaching aids for us in schools, colleges, adult education, business, and industrial training and home study.{{Cite web|url=http://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1962/03/04/83489076.html?pageNumber=138|title=CROWELL-COLLIER FORMS A NEW UNIT|website=timesmachine.nytimes.com|access-date=2016-04-20}} Other acquisitions included the following: * English Language Services, Inc. (1962), instructional materials used abroad to teach English-as-a-second language.{{Cite web|url=http://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1962/08/15/83224082.html?pageNumber=42|title=Crowell-Collier Unit in Deal|website=timesmachine.nytimes.com|access-date=2016-04-23}} * Publication Corporation (1968){{Cite web|url=http://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1968/05/08/88943240.html?pageNumber=72|title=Crowell Collier|website=timesmachine.nytimes.com|access-date=2016-04-20}} * Associated Films, Inc. (1968), an educational film distribution company * P.J. Kenedy & Sons (1968), a publisher of Catholic religion and educational books.{{Cite web|url=http://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1968/10/20/91236659.html?pageNumber=264|title=Expansion Planned By Crowell Collier|website=timesmachine.nytimes.com|access-date=2016-04-21}} * Hagstram Company, Inc (1968), creator of educational materials and services.{{Cite web|url=http://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1968/07/15/77094278.html?pageNumber=43|title=4 Concerns Bought By Crowell Collier|website=timesmachine.nytimes.com|access-date=2016-04-21}} * Fleetwood Films, Inc. (1968), films for home and educational use. * Pandex, Inc, (1968) a reference company. * Brandon (1968), another education and film distribution company.{{Cite web|url=http://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1968/09/18/76933695.html?pageNumber=52|title=Crowell Collier, Macmillan Purchases Brandon Films|website=timesmachine.nytimes.com|access-date=2016-04-21}} * G. Schirmer, Inc.,(1968) a music and publishing company * Studio Vista, Ltd. (1968)—British publisher of books on graphic arts, architecture and design.{{Cite web|url=http://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1968/08/25/91290818.html?pageNumber=219|title=Acquisition Slated|website=timesmachine.nytimes.com|access-date=2016-04-23}} * [[RCL Benziger|Benziger Brothers]] (1969)—publishers of religious and education books.{{Cite web|url=http://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1969/01/01/issue.html|title=The New York Times: Wednesday January 1, 1969|website=timesmachine.nytimes.com|access-date=2016-04-24}} * Cassell & Co. Holdings, Ltd, (1969). a British publishing company.{{Cite web|url=http://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1969/12/25/78550362.html?pageNumber=50|title=University Computing in Move;; LTV Aerospace to Sell COMPANIES PLAN MERGER ACTIONS|website=timesmachine.nytimes.com|access-date=2016-04-24}} * Standard Rate & Data Services, Inc., a publisher of advertising and marketing data.{{Cite web|url=http://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1969/01/17/77319317.html?pageNumber=37|title=Ad Data Agency To Be Acquired By Crowell Collier; COMPANIES TAKE MERGER ACTIONS|website=timesmachine.nytimes.com|access-date=2016-04-21}} === Home study and vocational training === [[File:La Salle Extension University Alumni Pin.png|thumb|left|upright|La Salle Extension University Alumni Pin]] [[Vocational education|Vocational training]] became big business in the 1960s as companies attempted fill a void between a [[High school diplomas|high school diploma]] and [[Academic degree|college degrees]] and Crowell-Collier made significant acquisitions expanding into this market.{{Cite web|url=http://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1969/12/07/issue.html|title=The New York Times: Sunday December 7, 1969|website=timesmachine.nytimes.com|access-date=2016-04-24}} In 1960, Crowell purchased the [[La Salle Extension University]]—a correspondence school. In 1965 Crowell Collier & Macmillan, Inc. purchased [[Berlitz Corporation|Berlitz Schools]] of Languages of America, Inc.and Berlitz Publications for $5 million.{{Cite web|url=http://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1965/12/16/95920643.html?pageNumber=75|title=Bid Set for Berlitz By Crowell Collier; CROWELL COLLIER BIDS FOR BERLITZ|website=timesmachine.nytimes.com|access-date=2016-04-20}}{{Cite web|url=http://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1966/02/05/461075662.html?pageNumber=44|title=Atlas Credit Planning Merger With Sunset Petroleum Corp.|website=timesmachine.nytimes.com|access-date=2016-04-21}} Crowell purchased [[Gibbs College|Katherine Gibbs School, Inc.]] a secretarial school.{{Cite web|url=http://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1968/07/30/issue.html|title=The New York Times: Tuesday July 30, 1968|website=timesmachine.nytimes.com|access-date=2016-04-21}} It also attempted to acquire [[Famous Artists School|Famous Artists Schools, Inc]]. a writing and art correspondence school by purchasing 25% of shares which it later sold to institutional investors in 1968.{{Cite web|url=http://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1965/08/08/98459047.html?pageNumber=125|title=Spotlight; Crowell Collier's Bid for School|website=timesmachine.nytimes.com|access-date=2016-04-21}}{{Cite web|url=http://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1968/01/20/79931708.html?pageNumber=40|title=Crowell Collier Receives $19.9-Million for Shares|website=timesmachine.nytimes.com|access-date=2016-04-21}} In 1969, Crowell filed a lawsuit against [[National Home Study Council]] of Washington which was a private accrediting agency. The suit said that National Home was a monopoly and had denied re-accreditation to the U.S. School of Music, Inc. and [[La Salle Extension University]].{{Cite web|url=http://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1969/12/16/78548553.html?pageNumber=43|title=Correspondence Schools Sue Accrediting Agency|website=timesmachine.nytimes.com|access-date=2016-04-23}} By 1969, Crowell made 22% of its revenue from La Salle Extension University, Berlitz, and Katharine Gibbs.{{Cite web|url=http://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1969/12/07/issue.html|title=The New York Times: Sunday December 7, 1969|website=timesmachine.nytimes.com|access-date=2016-04-24}} The lawsuit settled but at the same time, the entire mail-order schooling came under fire from the New York Times for dubious practices including "overblown advertising, fast talking salesmen, questionable instruction and marginal results."{{Cite web|url=http://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1970/05/31/354979102.html?pageNumber=39|title=Boom in Mail-Order Schooling Marked by Dubious Practices; Mail Order Schooling Beset by Problems|website=timesmachine.nytimes.com|access-date=2016-04-24}} === Return to magazines === In 1968 the company merged with '''Publication Corporation''', a leading printer of Sunday magazines for newspapers and the publisher of ''[[This Week (magazine)|This Week magazine]]''. The companies had a shared history—[[Joseph P. Knapp]], who had helped develop the Crowell Publishing Company, had founded Publication Corporation as '''American Lithograph Company''' in 1891. The Publication had also been a principal stockholder of Crowell-Collier—owning 24% at one point.{{Cite web|url=http://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1968/01/10/88920146.html?pageNumber=41|title=CROWELL COLLIER PLANNING MERGER; Offers $33-Million Stock to Publication Corp., Printers|website=timesmachine.nytimes.com|access-date=2016-04-23}} The goal for the merger was to distribute periodicals efficiently in the education market. By 1969, Crowell made the decision to shut down the ''This Week'' magazine which had a circulation of 9 million as a weekend supplement for papers such as ''[[The Providence Journal]]'' and ''[[the Kansas City Star]]''.{{Cite web|url=http://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1969/08/14/78391331.html?pageNumber=27|title=This Week Magazine Ends Publication Nov. 2; 39 Subscribers Given Option to Continue Section on Own But 15 Newspapers Cancel Contracts for Supplement|website=timesmachine.nytimes.com|access-date=2016-04-23}} In 1969 Crowell Collier & Macmillan went back to publishing magazines but with a focus on education.{{Cite web|url=http://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1969/04/15/90092742.html?pageNumber=70|title=Advertising: 6 Crowell Collier Specialties|website=timesmachine.nytimes.com|access-date=2016-04-21}} They acquired six magazines including ''Grade Teacher'', ''the Catholic School Journal'', ''Industrial Arts'' and ''Vocational Education'', ''College Management'', ''School Management'' and ''Business Management''. These magazines made up a subsidiary CCM magazines based in Greenwich, Conn. ==== Other media ==== Crowell-Collier Broadcasting operated radio stations in Los Angeles, San Francisco and Minneapolis.{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1964/12/12/crowellcollier-elects-a-new-vice-president.html|title=Crowell-Collier Elects A New Vice President|date=1964-12-12|newspaper=The New York Times|issn=0362-4331|access-date=2016-04-21}} In 1969 Crowell-Collier purchased the [[Gump's]] store in San Francisco.{{Cite web|url=http://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1969/01/11/88979590.html?pageNumber=44|title=CROWELL COLLIER SET TO BUY GUMP'S|website=timesmachine.nytimes.com|access-date=2016-04-21}} Crowell-Collier purchased [[C.G. Conn]] a manufacturer of musical instruments in 1968.{{Cite web|url=http://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1968/10/16/88969885.html?pageNumber=64|title=Garden Seeks Office Building;; Talks With Penn Central|website=timesmachine.nytimes.com|access-date=2016-04-24}} In 1966 the company consolidated 1400 employees into a new building on 866 3rd Avenue called the Crowell Collier & Macmillan building.{{Cite web|url=http://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1966/09/17/121031431.html?pageNumber=23|title=Crowell Collier Moving Into Its New Quarters|website=timesmachine.nytimes.com|access-date=2016-04-21}} === 1970s === {{see also|Macmillan Publishers (United States)}} By the start of the 1970s, Crowell Collier & Macmillan was now a $400 million multinational producer of books and educational materials.{{Cite web|url=http://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1972/12/12/80804995.html?pageNumber=69|title=2 Macmillans Agree on Use of Name|website=timesmachine.nytimes.com|access-date=2016-04-25}} Crowell Collier & Macmillan decided to change the name of the company to [[Macmillan Publishers (United States)|Macmillan, Inc]]. First, though, they encountered a legal battle over the name with Macmillan, Ltd. of London—who had spun-off from the original American Macmillan in 1896. For the name to take effect on January 1, 1973,{{Cite web|url=http://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1973/01/03/93251013.html?pageNumber=57|title=Canadian Javelin Chief Bows Out; People and Business|website=timesmachine.nytimes.com|access-date=2016-04-25}} the companies agreed to some conditions including the American company using Crowell-Collier or another name to distinguish the businesses in which the British Macmillan operated. The British Macmillan stated that the name had already been causing confusion with the public resulting in misdirected book orders and the fear that the American company was planning to use the name to compete unfairly in markets where the British company was active. The case cited the [[Lanham Act]], the trademark act of 1946. [[File:Harvard Classics books on a bookshelf.jpg|thumb|Harvard Classics books on a bookshelf]] This was not the only legal battle that the now Macmillan, Inc. faced at the start of the seventies. Macmillan sued Charles F. Berlitz, grandson of the founder of Berlitz to prohibit him from using the Berlitz name in travel and writing businesses.{{Cite web|url=http://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1970/01/03/80012303.html?pageNumber=27|title=Berlitz Taking Legalese To Win Use of Name|website=timesmachine.nytimes.com|access-date=2016-04-24}} Berlitz won the lawsuit and was awarded $376,000 and the right to use his name as an author of books on foreign languages.{{Cite web|url=http://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1973/04/14/79850367.html?pageNumber=36|title=A Berlitz Gets Right To Use His Name On Language Books|website=timesmachine.nytimes.com|access-date=April 25, 2016}} The Justice Department filed a civil anti-trust suit against Crowell, Collier & Macmillan, Inc. in 1970 and requested that it divest itself from C.G. Conn, Ltd (a manufacturer and retailer of musical instruments) and Uniforms by Ostwald, Inc. (manufacturer and retailer of band uniforms).{{Cite web|url=http://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1970/02/05/80019430.html?pageNumber=57|title=CROWELL COLLIER NAMED IN U.S. SUIT; Divestiture of Ostwald and Conn Concerns Is Sought|website=timesmachine.NYTimes.com|access-date=April 24, 2016}} Crowell-Collier was also under fire by the FTC again in 1972 and accused of using deceptive practices in selling its Harvard Classics and in billing encyclopedia buyers and also in recruiting of encyclopedia salesmen. Of the Harvard Classics, the FTC stated that while the company marketed that one or several volumes were offered free or for $1 each "with the understanding that additional volumes priced at $3.98 would be shipped periodically for free examination", many volumes would be shipped in a bulk shipment. Buyers were subjected to repeated mailings of bills. Crowell responded that they had already discontinued the Harvard Classics "continuity" program and that any "isolated" occurrences or procedures had been changed. For the encyclopedias, Crowell was accused of raising the price on Encyclopedia annual supplements called Yearbooks. They were also accused of advertising positions for encyclopedia salesman as "administrative assistant trainees" and "marketing and public relations personnel". Crowell issued a statement disavowing any violations but agreed to negotiate a consent order.{{Cite web|url=http://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1972/02/29/93415819.html?pageNumber=8|title=BOOK PUBLISHER ACCUSED BY F.T.C.; Deceptive Practices Alleged in Encyclopedia Sales|website=timesmachine.NYTimes.com|access-date=April 25, 2016}} [[Martin Gardner]] protesting Crowell-Collier's publishing of the [[psychic surgery|psychic surgeon]] [[John G. Fuller]]'s book ''Arigo'' withdrew publication of his own (Gardner) book.{{cite journal |last1=Ward |first1=Ray |title=The Martin Gardner Correspondence with Marcello Truzzi |journal=Skeptical Inquirer |date=2017 |volume=41 |issue=6 |pages=57-59 |publisher=Committee for Skeptical Inquiry}} ==Magazines == * ''[[Farm & Fireside]]'' (1877–1939): The early content of this magazine advertised agricultural implements manufactured by P. P. Mast & Co. When farming became a commercialized industry, ''Farm & Fireside'' changed to address it commercial and economic aspects and provided a first-hand account of America's conversion from a rural to an urban population. * ''[[Woman's Home Companion]]'' (1883–1950): The popularity of the women's section of ''Farm & Fireside'' created a demand for a publication dedicated to women. The company acquired ''The Home Companion'' magazine in 1883 and changed the name to ''Ladies Home Companion'' and then later to ''Women's Home Companion''. * ''[[The American Magazine]]'' (1911–1956): The magazine began as ''[[Leslie's Popular Monthly]]'' in 1876 and was then sold in 1906 to [[muckraker]]s [[Ray Stannard Baker|Ray Stannard Barker]], [[Ida Tarbell]], and [[Lincoln Steffens|Lincoln Steffans]]. The periodical addressed the hopes and aspirations of the ordinary man was purchased by Crowell-Collier in 1911. * ''[[Collier's]]'' (1919–1956): The magazine was originally established by Peter Fenelon Collier in New York in 1888. It was purchased by Crowell Publishing in 1919 and ceased publication in 1956.{{Cite web|url=http://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1957/05/26/issue.html|title=The New York Times: Sunday May 26, 1957|website=timesmachine.nytimes.com|access-date=2016-04-20}} * ''The Mentor'' (1921–1930): This magazine focused on topics including science, art, history, literature and travel. ''The Mentor'' merged with the ''World Traveler'' in 1930 as the ''Mentor-World Traveler'' and ceased publication that same year. == References == {{Reflist}} == External links == {{Commons category|Crowell-Collier Publishing Company}} * [http://abandonedonline.net/exploring-crowell-collier/ Crowell-Collier Publishing Company] at Abandoned * [http://archives.nypl.org/mss/703 Crowell-Collier Publishing Company records 1931–1955] at [[New York Public Library]] [[Category:Articles created via the Article Wizard]] [[Category:Collier's]] [[Category:Defunct book publishing companies of the United States]] [[Category:Defunct publishing companies]] [[Category:Educational book publishing companies]] [[Category:Educational publishing companies]] [[Category:Magazine publishing companies]] [[Category:1877 establishments in the United States]] [[Category:1973 disestablishments in the United States]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox government agency |name = Department of Education |native_name = ''Kagawaran ng Edukasyon'' |type = Department |seal = Department of Education.svg |seal_caption = Seal |logo = Department of Education (DepEd).svg |logo_caption = Logo |formed = {{Start date|1901|01|21}} |preceding1 = Department of Public Instruction |preceding2 = Department of Public Instruction and Information |preceding3 = Department of Instruction |preceding4 = Department/Ministry of Education and Culture |preceding5 = Ministry/Department of Education, Culture and Sports |preceding6 = |dissolved = |jurisdiction = Philippines |headquarters = DepEd Complex, [[Meralco Avenue]], [[Pasig|Pasig City]], [[Metro Manila]], [[Philippines]] |coordinates = {{coord|14|34|44.47|N|121|3|53.57|E|type:landmark|display=inline}} | employees = |budget = {{Philippine peso|553,312,832,000.00}} (2018)<ref>{{cite web|title=GAA 2018|url=https://www.rappler.com/move-ph/issues/budget-watch/191632-government-office-2018-national-budget-overview|work=DBM|accessdate=25 January 2018}}</ref> |chief1_name = [[Leonor Briones|Leonor Magtolis Briones]] |chief1_position = Secretary |chief2_name = |chief2_position = | chief3_name = | chief3_position = | chief4_name = | chief4_position = | chief5_name = | chief5_position = | chief6_name = | chief6_position = | chief7_name = | chief7_position = | chief8_name = | chief8_position = | chief9_name = | chief9_position = | parent_department = |parent_agency = |child1_agency = |child2_agency = |website = {{URL|www.deped.gov.ph}} |footnotes = |logo_width = |seal_width = 200px |picture = Department Of Education (DepED) (Ultra Complex, Meralco Ave., Pasig; 2012-11).jpg |picture_width = |picture_caption = Department of Education building |superseding = }}
The '''Department of Education''' (abbreviated as '''DepEd'''; {{lang-fil|Kagawaran ng Edukasyon}}) is the [[Executive Departments of the Philippines|executive department]] of the [[Government of the Philippines|Philippine government]] responsible for ensuring access to, promoting equity in, and improving the quality of basic education.<ref name="RA 9155">{{cite web|url=http://www.chanrobles.com/republicactno9155.html |title=Republic Act No. 9155 |work=Chan Robles Virtual Law Library |accessdate=1 November 2012}}</ref> It is the main agency tasked to manage and govern the Philippine system of [[basic education]]. It is the chief formulator of Philippine education policy and responsible for the Philippine primary and secondary school systems. It has its headquarters at the DepEd Complex in [[Meralco Avenue]], [[Pasig City]].
The department is currently led by the [[Secretary of Education (Philippines)|Secretary of Education]], nominated by the [[President of the Philippines]] and confirmed by the [[Commission on Appointments (Philippines)|Commission on Appointments]]. The Secretary is a member of the [[Cabinet of the Philippines|Cabinet]]. The current Secretary of Education is [[Leonor Briones]]. Presently, its mission is to provide quality basic education that is equitably accessible to all and lay the foundation for lifelong learning and service for the common good. It has changed its vision statement, removing a phrase that some groups deem to be "too sectarian" for a government institution.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.abs-cbnnews.com/nation/08/23/14/deped-changes-vision-statement-removes-god-loving |title=DepEd changes vision statement, removes 'God-loving' |work=ABS-CBNnews.com |date=2014-08-23}}</ref>
==History== During the early [[Spain|Spanish]] period, [[education in the Philippines]] was [[religion]]-oriented and was primarily for the elite, especially in the first years of Spanish colonization. Access to education by Filipinos was later liberalized through the enactment of the Educational Decree of 1863, which provided for the establishment of at least one [[primary school]] for boys and girls in each town under the responsibility of the municipal government, and the establishment of a [[normal school]] for male teachers under the supervision of the [[Jesuits]]. Primary instruction was secularized and free, and the teaching of Spanish was compulsory. It was also through this decree that the 'Superior Commission of Primary Instruction' was established, the seminal agency of the Department of Education.<ref name="DepEd History">{{cite web|url=http://www.deped.gov.ph/about_deped/history.asp |title=Department of Education of the Philippines - DepEd - History |accessdate=1 November 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100722150827/http://www.deped.gov.ph/about_deped/history.asp |archivedate=22 July 2010 |df= }}</ref>
The defeat of Spain by [[United States]] forces in 1898 paved the way for [[Emilio Aguinaldo|Aguinaldo]]'s Republic under a Revolutionary Government. The schools maintained by Spain for more than three centuries were closed temporarily but were reopened on August 29, 1898 by the Secretary of the Interior. A system of free and compulsory elementary education was established by the [[Malolos Constitution]], under Article 23. However, this first sovereign education system was interrupted in 1899 with the start of the [[Philippine–American War]], and was finally dismantled.
A secularized and free [[Public school (government funded)|public school]] system during the first decade of American rule was established upon the recommendation of the [[Schurman Commission]] in 1900. Free primary instruction that trained the people for the duties of citizenship was enforced by the [[Taft Commission]] as per instructions of [[President of the United States|US President]] [[William McKinley]]. Chaplains and non-commissioned officers were assigned to teach using English as the medium of instruction.<ref name="DepEd History"/>
A highly centralized public school system was instituted in January 1901 by the Taft Commission, by virtue of Act No. 74. This act also established the '''Department of Public Instruction''', headed by a General Superintendent. The implementation of this Act created a heavy shortage of teachers so the Philippine Commission authorized the Superintendent of Public Instruction to brin 500 teachers from the [[United States]] to the Philippines. They would later be popularly known as the [[Thomasites]].
In 1908, the [[Philippine Legislature]] approved Act No. 1870, creating the [[University of the Philippines]].
The [[Jones Law (Philippines)|Organic Act of 1916]] reorganized the Department of Public Instruction, mandating that it be headed by a Secretary. This act also mandated the Filpinization of department secretaries, except that of the Secretary of Public Instruction.
During [[World War II]], the department was reorganized once again through the Japanese's Military Order No. 2 in February 1942, splitting the department into the '''Ministry of Education''' and the Ministry of Health, Labor and Public Instruction. Under the Japanese, the teaching of Tagalog, Philippine history, and character education was given priority. Love for work and the [[dignity of labor]] were also emphasized.
In October 1944, months after Pres. [[Manuel L. Quezon]]'s death, the department was renamed as the '''Department of Public Instruction and Information''', with [[Carlos P. Romulo]] at the helm. Upon the return and resumption of the [[Commonwealth of the Philippines|Commonwealth Government]] in February 1945, its name was changed to the '''Department of Instruction'''.
In 1947, by virtue of Executive Order No. 94 by Pres. [[Manuel Roxas]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gov.ph/1947/10/04/executive-order-no-94-s-1947/ |title=Executive Order No. 94, s. 1947 |work=Official Gazette of the Republic of the Philippines |accessdate=1 November 2012}}</ref> the department was reorganized to the '''Department of Education'''. During this period, the regulation and supervision of public and private schools belonged to the Bureau of Public and Private Schools.
Upon the start of [[Martial law in the Philippines|Martial Law]] in September 1972, it became the '''Department of Education and Culture''' and subsequently reorganized into the '''Ministry of Education and Culture''' in June 1978 by virtue of Presidential Decree No. 1397,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.chanrobles.com/presidentialdecrees/presidentialdecreeno1397.html |title=Presidential Decree No. 1397 |work=Chan Robles Virtual Law Library |accessdate=1 November 2012}}</ref> due to the shift to a [[parliamentary system of government]]. Thirteen regional offices were created and major organizational changes were implemented in the educational system.
The Education Act of 1982<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lawphil.net/statutes/bataspam/bp1982/bp_232_1982.html |title=Batas Pambansa Blg. 232 |work=The LAWPHiL Project |accessdate=1 November 2012}}</ref> created the '''Ministry of Education, Culture and Sports''', which became the '''Department of Education, Culture and Sports (DECS)''' in 1987 via Executive Order No. 117<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lawphil.net/executive/execord/eo1987/eo_117_1987.html |title=Executive Order No. 117 |work=The LAWPHiL Project |accessdate=1 November 2012}}</ref> by President [[Corazon C. Aquino]].
The structure of DECS as embodied in EO 117 has practically remained unchanged until 1994, when the [[Commission on Higher Education (Philippines)|Commission on Higher Education]] (CHED) was established, and in August 25, 1994, when the [[Technical Education and Skills Development Authority]] (TESDA) was established to supervise tertiary degree programs and non-degree technical-vocational programs, respectively. The trifocal education system refocused the department's mandate to basic education which covers elementary, secondary and non-formal education, including culture and sports. CHED is responsible for tertiary education, while TESDA now administers the post-secondary, middle-level manpower training and development.<ref name="DepEd History"/>
In August 2001, the Governance of Basic Education Act<ref name="RA 9155"/> was passed, renaming the DECS to the '''Department of Education (DepEd)''' and redefining the role of field offices, which include regional offices, division offices, district offices, and schools.
The Act removed the administration of cultural and sports activities from the department. The National Historical Institute, Records Management and Archives Office, and the National Library are now administratively attached to the [[National Commission for Culture and the Arts]] (NCCA). All previous functions, programs, and activities related to sports competition were transferred to the [[Philippine Sports Commission]] (PSC). In addition, the Bureau of Physical Education and School Sports was abolished.
==List of Secretaries of Education== {{main|Secretary of Education (Philippines)}}
==Organizational structure== At present, the Department is headed by the [[Secretary of Education (Philippines)|Secretary of Education]], with the following undersecretaries and assistant secretaries: *Undersecretary for Accounting *Undersecretary for Administration *Undersecretary for Curriculum and Instruction *Undersecretary for Legal Affairs *Undersecretary for Finance *Undersecretary for Planning and Field Operations *Assistant Secretary/Chief of Staff *Assistant Secretary for Procurement *Assistant Secretary for Liaison and Partnerships *Assistant Secretary for Public Affairs and Alternative Learning System
Under the Office of the Secretary are the following offices and services: *Teacher Education Council *Literacy Coordinating Council *Internal Audit Service
A director is assigned to each of the 17 [[regions of the Philippines]]; the [[Autonomous Region in Muslim Mindanao]] is governed by a regional secretary. A division superintendent is assigned to each of the school divisions defined by the department.
===Bureaus and services=== DepEd is composed of 18 bureaus and services:<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.deped.gov.ph/directory.asp |title=Directory of Officials - Department of Education |accessdate=14 January 2017}}</ref> *Administrative Service (AS) *Bureau of Curriculum Development (BCD) *Bureau of Education Assessment (BEA) *Bureau of Human Resources and Organizational Development (BHROD) *Bureau of Learning Delivery (BLD) *Bureau of Learning Resources (BLR) *Bureau of Learner Support Service (BLSS) *Bureau of Secondary Education (BSE) *Disaster Risk Reduction and Management Service (DRRMS) *External Partnerships Service (EPS) *Finance Service (FS) *Information and Communications Technology Service (ICTS) *Legal Service (LS) *National Educators' Academy of the Philippines (NEAP) *Planning Service (PS) *Procurement Service (PROCS) *Project Management Service (PMS) *Public Affairs Service (PAS)
==Attached agencies== The following agencies, councils and schools are attached to DepEd for policy and program coordination: * Department of Education in the ARMM (DepEd ARMM) * Instructional Materials Council (IMC) * [[National Book Development Board (Philippines)|National Book Development Board]] (NBDB) * National Council for Children's Television (NCCT) * [[National Museum of the Philippines]] * National Science Teaching Instrumentation Center (NSTIC) * [[Philippine High School for the Arts]] (PHSA)
The [[Commission on Higher Education (Philippines)|Commission on Higher Education]] (CHED) is now attached to the Office of the President, while the [[Technical Education and Skills Development Authority]] (TESDA) is now attached to the [[Department of Labor and Employment (Philippines)|Department of Labor and Employment]].
==References== {{Reflist}}
{{Executive Departments of the Philippines}} {{Department of Education of the Philippines}} {{Ortigas Center}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Department of Education (Philippines)}} [[Category:Education ministries|Philippines]] [[Category:Department of Education (Philippines)| ]] [[Category:Ministries established in 1901|Philippines, Education]] [[Category:Executive departments of the Philippines|Education]]

revision.text:
{{Refimprove|date=December 2009}}
'''Deweyism''' is the [[philosophy of education]] expounded by [[John Dewey]] in his 1897 article "[[S:My Pedagogic Creed|My Pedagogic Creed]]".<ref name="PC">Dewey, John (1897). My Pedagogic Creed. ''School Journal'', 54(3), 77–80.</ref> It emphasized social interaction and group learning over individual education, and became the dominant influence on American education.{{citation needed|date=January 2016}}
==Review of John Dewey's ''My Pedagogic Creed''==
===What education is=== According to [[John Dewey]]'s article "[[S:My Pedagogic Creed|My Pedagogic Creed]]" (1897),<ref name="PC"/> education is only as individual as our society allows it to be. We (people) are unconsciously trained from birth. Our social consciousness, our cultural ways and what we value are a mock up of a collective social being, according to Dewey. We are all a product of our social surroundings from birth through adulthood and death. Eventually we "become an inheritor of the funded capital of civilization." Dewey exerts that individual best is achieved in the spirit of and for the greater good. "Through these demands he is stimulated to act as a member of a unity, to emerge from his original narrowness of action and feeling and to conceive of himself from the standpoint of the welfare of the group to which he belongs." As a member of society, we are confined to language and its meanings, but also empowered by it.
Dewey believes that "the educational process has two sides." Psychological and sociological impacts are two sides of the education process that go hand-in-hand; "neither can be subordinated to the other or neglected without evil results following." Psychology provides the foundation of education while sociology provides the scenario. Unless what is taught and how we teach relates to students' lives, it can become stressful. Even good grades are not indicative of authentic learning. Students may become disenfranchised. Psychology and social dynamics must exist in conjunction with each other to create a truly internal experience. It is important to know what is happening in the world-at-large, according to Dewey. One must also look at the student's world to ensure success relevant to their own realm of accomplishment. "We must also be able to project them into the future to see what their outcome and end will be." Dewey holds that we must look into the individual future of every student and see what their own outlook is and how we can get there—not a collective outlook defined by blanket societal expectations of success by every person. Dewey states, "To know what a power really is we must know what its end, use, or function is." In sum, a student cannot achieve power over their future until they know what their future can be. Teachers cannot prepare students for a future we cannot foretell as a result of ever-changing technology. People can truly prepare for the future by empowering students. In Dewey's words, "To prepare him for the future life means to give him command of himself." Hands-on learning that utilizes the senses and capacity of the student creates the most success, intrinsically and externally. Dewey believes "that the individual who is to be educated as a social individual and that society is an organic union of individuals." Demonstration of this success shows a psychological process. Utilizing the skills derived from effective psychological learning, social factors can be successfully recognized and addressed.
===Schools=== Education is a social process. According to the creed, it should not be used for the purposes of preparation for living in the future. Dewey said, "I believe that education, therefore, is a process of living and not a preparation for future living." We can build a child's self-esteem in not only the classroom but in all aspects of his or her life. Education must always stay true to children and align with their reality in order to be true. Dewey argues that some children are over labeled and misunderstood because we take away authentic experiences by not relating education to natural human order. More importantly he emphasizes, "Existing life is so complex that the child cannot be brought into contact with it without either confusion or distraction….and he becomes either unduly specialized or else disintegrated."
Dewey believes that education and school ought to be an extension of home. Personal background is psychological and gives way to new ideas. This is summed up in the quote, "It is the business of the school to deepen and extend his sense of the values bound up in his home life." In schools currently, the information is given, lessons are learned and habits are formed, similar to the [[banking model of education]] criticised by [[Paulo Freire]] in his 1970 book ''[[Pedagogy of the Oppressed]]''.<ref>Freire, Paulo. ''Pedagogy of the Oppressed''. New York: Continuum, 2007 [1970].</ref> Dewey states that this is not effective. Working together is vital to unity and success. He states, "The present educational systems, so far as they destroy or neglect this unity, render it difficult or impossible to get any genuine, regular moral meanings." We need to see school as a social experience, according to this creed. The teacher is the guide and chooses what relevant experience will guide each child through the education process. When it comes to assessment, Dewey states that grading should be relevant to the child's own progress. Exams are to be used for social ordering rather than individual upkeep.
===The subject-matter of education=== Following suit with his other theories, Dewey believes that subject matter should reflect students' real lives. Schools focus on too many subjects, which may not reflect the students' actual experiences. The child's own activities should determine curriculum. For example, students are often given literature lessons at the beginning of the learning experience, when it is the sum of events, making the subject relevant for the end of learning; This gives the student time to shape his or her own views before being told how history or some one else has seen something. It should be given at the end as a summative reflection.
We need to let children be constructive and pave their own paths, according to Dewey. "I believe that the only way to make a child conscious of his social heritage is to enable him to perform those fundamental types of activity which makes civilization what it is." Dewey takes on a constructive point of view. He says that at times vocations may be more relevant and should be main subjects. In order to learn formal subjects, students need to be relaxed. Dewey explains that in order to achieve that, they must be comfortable with what they have learned up to that point. All subjects are relevant to life.
===Method=== # Dewey asserts that active participation far surpasses passive learning. Action must come before anything else. We create children's negative perceptions of school. Ideas come from movement. Symbols give an inaccurate and incomplete view of the big picture. They impact the student's ability to think authentically. # Envisioning the message helps with retention. Imagery is so important in generating relevancy to one's life. # It is the teacher's job to pay attention to student's blooming interests and expand on them for a one of a kind learning experience. Interest is power and we must harbor that interest. # Welcome emotions in education. They are part of the important aspects of learning.
===School and social progress=== In Dewey's words, "education is the fundamental method of social progress and reform." Social consciousness shapes individual perceptions. Society also has an obligation to reform education. As a society we are responsible for one another. "I believe it is the business of every one interested in education to insist upon the school as the primary and most effective instrument of social progress and reform in order that society may be awakened to realize what the school stands for, and aroused to the necessity of endowing the educator with sufficient equipment properly to perform his task." Education is the perfect combination of art and science. Dewey sees that we must use individuality for the greater good. Dewey recognizes that teaching is noble and selfless. Teachers show us our way.
==References== <references />
[[Category:Pedagogy]] [[Category:Critical pedagogy]] [[Category:Philosophy of education]]
