revision.text:
'''Dickinson College Commentaries''' <ref>[http://dcc.dickinson.edu/ Dickinson College Commentaries]</ref> is a digital project of [[Dickinson College]], which is located in [[Carlisle, Pennsylvania|Carlisle]], near [[Harrisburg]], in the U.S. state of [[Pennsylvania]]. The project assembles digital commentaries on texts in Latin and ancient Greek and publishes core vocabularies of the most common words in those languages. It is hosted by the department of [[Classical Studies]].
== History == In 2010 DCC launched a pilot site in [[MediaWiki]] that was dedicated to notes on the selections from [[Gallic Wars]] used in the American [[Advanced Placement]] Latin Exam.<ref>[http://apcentral.collegeboard.com/apc/members/exam/exam_information/4558.html Advanced Placement Latin Exam]</ref> The site moved to [[Drupal]] <ref>[https://www.drupal.org/ Drupal]</ref> in 2012. The project director is Christopher Francese, the Asbury J. Clarke Professor of Classical Studies at Dickinson College.
== Peer Review == Commentary proposals are reviewed and edited in a process similar to that used by traditional academic print publishers.
== Copyright status == Dickinson College Commentaries supports [[open-source]] content, and publishes all content under a [[Creative Commons]] CC-BY-SA license.
== External links == * [http://dcc.dickinson.edu/ Dickinson College Commentaries] * [http://dco.dickinson.edu/ Dickinson Classics Online] (Chinese sister project) * [http://tcl.camws.org/sites/default/files/TCL%20Spring%202014%20Mahoney.pdf Anne Mahoney, “Latin Commentaries on the Web.” Teaching Classical Languages 5.2 (2014): 133–143.]
== References == {{Reflist}}
[[Category:Computing in classical studies]] [[Category:Discipline-oriented digital libraries]] [[Category:Educational projects]] [[Category:Digital humanities]] [[Category:Dickinson College]]

revision.comment: Reverted edits by [[Special:Contribs/94.100.221.201|94.100.221.201]] ([[User talk:94.100.221.201|talk]]) to last version by InternetArchiveBot
revision.text:
'''E-mentoring''' is a means of providing a guided mentoring relationship using [[Cloud computing|online software]] or [[email]]. It stemmed from [[mentoring]] programs with the invention of the internet, and began to gain popularity around 1993. First used for programs connecting schoolchildren with business people, e-mentoring is now popular throughout [[United States|the US]], [[United Kingdom|the UK]], and some parts of [[Europe]]. A very recent development is websites offering online mentoring (not just matching of a mentor and a mentee).
== Early e-mentoring ==
Many early e-mentoring programs used [[email]] communication to link mentors and mentees. [[Telephone]] communication was also occasionally used, known as telementoring. One of the first e-mentoring programs was developed in [[Canada]] in 1990, where teachers from schools in [[British Columbia]] were given online support and training by experienced peers. The teachers and peers never met in a [[Face-to-face (philosophy)|face-to-face]] context.<ref>"Mentoring: students and young people" Andrew Miller, 2002</ref>
== Web-based e-mentoring ==
Modern e-mentoring projects tend to rely on [[Web application|web-based]] solutions,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.aimhighersw.ac.uk/cases/casestudy31.htm |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2008-09-25 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081024133434/http://www.aimhighersw.ac.uk/cases/casestudy31.htm |archivedate=2008-10-24 |df= }}</ref> particularly if children are involved. Online [[software]] allows both mentors and mentees to log into a secure online environment where they can converse under [[supervision]] of moderators and coordinators.
An example of an e-mentoring organization is in the US is MentorNet,<ref>[http://www.mentornet.net Mentoring in Engineering and Science - MentorNet]</ref> a non-profit e-mentoring organization that focuses on women and underrepresented minorities in the STEM (Science, Technology, Engineering and Mathematics) fields. MentorNet uses an algorithm to match over 27,000 mentor relationships since 1997. The organization is unique because it uses technology to guide relationships between mentors and protégés. MentorNet focuses on college-level protégés for the 8-month matching scheme. Another US provider is Chronus who provide eMentoring services across various sectors from enterprise to non-profit.
An example of an e-mentoring provider in the UK is Brightside,<ref>[http://www.thebrightsidetrust.org Brightside - home]</ref> a non-profit e-mentoring organization that works with 60 businesses, charities and universities. Brightside has developed a secure online portal featuring interactive content and resources through which over 6,000 trained online mentors are connected with over 21,000 young people, providing them with information and guidance about education and employment. Newer entrants to the UK market include sfG MentorNet®,<ref>[http://www.sfgmentornet.com sfG MentorNet® Website]</ref> which was designed jointly with a youth-based mentoring charity but which is also now being used by an increasing number of Careers Departments within UK universities. Others include Aluminati with their Aluminate eMentoring platform<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.aluminati.net/app/aluminate-portal/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2015-06-30 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150626052609/http://www.aluminati.net/app/aluminate-portal |archivedate=2015-06-26 |df= }}</ref> targeted to alumni and students of higher educational institutions<ref>[http://www.aluminati.net/clients/]</ref> and Mentor Match Me.<ref>[http://www.mentormatchme.com/]</ref>
Online mentoring websites attempt to offer a knowledge base with access mechanisms so a user can get mentoring advice comparable to the advice they could get from an experienced mentor -- but get the advice directly from their smartphone, tablet or computer, without having to communicate with a human. One example of this kind of e-mentoring is the MyCareerMentor app. <ref>[http://www.stepup.work]</ref>
==E-mentoring mediums== E-mentoring can retain the face to face interaction by utilizing video chat services, such as [[FaceTime]], [[Google Hangouts]], [[Skype]], video chat through [[Facebook]], etc.
== Controversy and debate ==
Online mentoring is occasionally compared unfavourably with face to face [[mentoring]]. The medium limits the ability to pick up on visual or social clues, makes immediate feedback difficult and can often be seen as impersonal.{{citation needed|date=September 2011}}
However, e-mentoring can make participants more willing to offer honest feedback.<ref>"Interpersonal effects in computer-mediated interaction: a relational perspective" JB Walther 1992</ref> It is also being embraced more readily by those in business who want to become mentors, as e-mentoring is less time-consuming than face-to-face mentoring.<ref>[http://healthcare.advancementoring.com/index.php?FindPage=Advantages+of+our+hybrid+e+mentoring,+telementorin&LayoutSet=short Advance Mentoring - Database Error]</ref>
== Impact ==
It has been suggested that the quality of the mentoring relationship is heavily influenced by the amount of common interests that the mentor and mentee have. As such, most charities and businesses that offer eMentoring programmes require some shared interest between the mentor and mentee.<ref>[http://www.thebrightsidetrust.org/viewabout.php?aid=23 ] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081024031247/http://www.thebrightsidetrust.org/viewabout.php?aid=23 |date=October 24, 2008 }}</ref> It is also generally accepted that any mentoring relationship is most effective during a transitional period in the mentee's life, such as applying to university or making decisions about future careers.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.scottishmentoringnetwork.co.uk/uploads/documents/Hunt1.doc |accessdate=September 24, 2008 }}{{dead link|date=June 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}</ref>
E-mentoring programs also impact beneficially on the motivation of the youth pursuing post [[highschool]] studies. The impression, that is driven from the exchanges with an e-mentor working in the field of interests of the youth, of "how important the studies are" if he wants to get the job he dreams of is tangible.<ref>[http://academos.luka.ca/?BD9E0E81-3080-4AEA-A22F-B01DB6E2924E&lang=EN ]{{dead link|date=December 2013}}</ref>
== See also ==
*[[Youth mentoring]] *[[Protégé]] *[[Volunteering]] *[[Virtual volunteering]]
== Notes ==
{{reflist|1}} [http://www.seonortheast.co.uk/mentor/ Online Mentoring For Search Engine Optimization]
== External links == *{{dmoz|/Science/Educational_Resources/Mentoring_Programs/|Mentoring}}
[[Category:Distance education]]

revision.comment: removed [[Category:19th century in Scotland]]; added [[Category:1872 in Scotland]] using [[WP:HC|HotCat]]
revision.text:
{{Infobox UK legislation |short_title = Education (Scotland) Act 1872 |type = Act |parliament = Parliament of the United Kingdom |long_title = |year = 1872 |citation = 35 & 36 Vict. c. 62 |introduced_by = |territorial_extent = [[Scotland]] |si_made_date = |si_laid_date = |royal_assent = |commencement = |repeal_date = |replaces = |primary_legislation = |eu_directives = |amendments = |related_legislation = [[Elementary Education Act 1870]] <small>([[England and Wales|E&W]])</small> |repealing_legislation= |status = |original_text = |legislation_history = |use_new_UK-LEG = yes |UK-LEG_title = |revised_text = |theyworkforyou = |millbankhansard = }} The '''Education (Scotland) Act 1872''' (35 & 36 [[Queen Victoria|Vict]]. c. 62), also known as '''Forster's Education Act''' made [[primary education]] universal and mandatory in Scotland; poverty was no longer an excuse for truancy.
The act mandated the exclusive use of English-medium education in Scotland, in effect banning [[Scottish Gaelic medium education]]. For this reason it is credited with causing substantial harm to the [[Scottish Gaelic]] language and contributing to its overall decline.<ref name="BBC">{{cite web |title=1872 Education Act's impact on Gaelic to be explored |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-scotland-highlands-islands-19076304 |website=[[BBC News Online]] |accessdate=13 January 2017 }}</ref><ref>{{cite book |last=Robertson |first=Boyd |year=2001 |title=Gaelic: the Gaelic language in education in the UK |publisher=Mercator-Education |location=[[Leeuwarden]] |url=https://strathprints.strath.ac.uk/3233/ }}</ref>
==Background== In 1866 the government established the Argyll Commission, under [[Whigs (British political party)|Whig]] grandee [[George Campbell, 8th Duke of Argyll]], to look into the schooling system. It found that of 500,000 children in need of education 200,000 were receiving it under efficient conditions, 200,000 in schools of doubtful merit, without any inspection and 90,000 were receiving no education at all. Although this compared favourably with the situation in England, with 14% more children in education and with relatively low illiteracy rates of between 10 and 20%, similar to those in the best-educated nations such as those in [[Unification of Germany|Germany]], the [[Netherlands]], [[Switzerland]] and [[Scandinavia]], the report was used as support for widespread reform. The result was the 1872 Education (Scotland) Act, based on that passed for [[England and Wales]] as the [[Elementary Education Act 1870]], but providing a more comprehensive solution.<ref name=Checkland&Checkland1989pp112-13/>
==The Act== Under the act approximately 1,000 regional [[school boards in Scotland|school boards]] were established<ref name=Paterson2001pp566-9>{{cite book |first=L. |last=Patterson |chapter=Schools and schooling: 3. Mass education 1872–present |editor-first=Michael |editor-last=Lynch |title=The Oxford Companion to Scottish History |publisher=Oxford University Press |year=2001 |isbn=0-19-211696-7 |pages=566–9 }}</ref> and, unlike in England where they merely attempted to fill gaps in provision, immediately took over the schools of the old and new kirks and were able to begin to enforce attendance, rather than after the decade necessary in England.<ref name=Checkland&Checkland1989pp112-13/> Some ragged and industrial schools requested to be taken over by the boards, while others continued as Sunday schools.<ref name=Morton2012p181>{{cite book |first=Graeme |last=Morton |title=Ourselves and Others: Scotland 1832–1914 |publisher=Edinburgh University Press |year=2012 |isbn=0748620494 |page=181 }}</ref> All children aged from 5 to 13 years were to attend. Poverty was not accepted as an excuse and some help was supplied under the [[Scottish Poor Laws|Poor laws]]. This was enforced by the School Attendance Committee, while the boards busied themselves with building to fill the gaps in provision. This resulted in a major programme that created large numbers of grand, purpose-built schools.<ref name=Checkland&Checkland1989pp112-13>{{cite book |author1-first=Olive |author1-last=Checkland |author2-first=Sydney |author2-last=Checkland |title=Industry and Ethos: Scotland, 1832–1914 |publisher=Edinburgh University Press |year=1989 |isbn=0748601023 |pages=112–13 }}</ref> Overall administration was in the hands of the Scotch (later Scottish) Education Department in London.<ref name=nationalarchive>{{Citation |title=Education records |journal=[[National Archives of Scotland]] |year=2006 |url=http://www.nas.gov.uk/guides/education.asp |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5zt5P28yI?url=http://www.nas.gov.uk/guides/education.asp |archivedate=2 July 2011 |deadurl=yes }}</ref> Demand for places was high and for a generation after the act there was overcrowding in many classrooms, with up to 70 children being taught in one room. The emphasis on a set number of passes at exams also led to much learning by rote and the system of inspection led to even the weakest children being drilled with certain facts.<ref name=Checkland&Checkland1989pp112-13/>
==Effect on Gaelic== The Education (Scotland) Act 1872 effectively put an end to non-English medium education and repressed Gaelic with pupils being punished for speaking the language.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://openaccess.leidenuniv.nl/bitstream/handle/1887/18678/Language%20shift%20on%20Skye%20-%20printed%20version.pdf?sequence=2 |title=Gaelic Language Erosion and Revitalization on the Isle of Skye, Scotland |first1=Dick |last1=Smakman |first2=Cassandra |last2=Smith-Christmas |publisher=[[University of Leiden]] }}</ref> Pupils were belted if caught speaking in Gaelic and beaten again if they did not reveal the names of other students speaking Gaelic.<ref name="BBC"/> The effect of the education act upon the Gaelic language has been described as "disastrous"<ref name="google1">{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=0ldowI6VgeMC&pg=PA568 |title=The Edinburgh history of the Scots language |first=Charles |last=Jones |publisher=Edinburgh University Press |date=1997 |page=568 |accessdate=22 November 2011 }}</ref> and by denying the value of Gaelic culture and language, contributed to destroying the self-respect of Gaelic communities.<ref name="sorrow" /> It was a continuation of a general policy (by both [[Parliament of Scotland|Scottish]] and, after [[Acts of Union 1707|1707]], [[Parliament of the United Kingdom|British]] governments) which aimed at [[Anglicisation]].<ref name="google1"/>
As a result of facing punishment and humiliation for speaking Gaelic, many parents decided not to pass on the language to their children, resulting in [[language shift]].<ref>{{cite book |first=Robert |last=Dunbar |editor-first1=Deirdre |editor-last1=Fottrell |editor-first2=Bill |editor-last2=Bowring |chapter=The European Charter for Regional and Minority Languages: Some Reflections from a Scottish Gaelic Perspective |title=Minority and Group Rights in the New Millennium |date=27 October 1999 |publisher=Martinus Nijhoff Publishers |page=117 |chapter-url=https://books.google.com/books?id=6sI_S_FoMfIC&pg=PA117 |accessdate=13 January 2017 }}</ref> [[Scottish Gaelic medium education]] was not established until the 1980s, and the impact of the Act is still being felt in Gaelic communities today.<ref name="BBC" /><ref name="sorrow">{{cite book |last1=Hunter |first1=James |title=On the Other Side of Sorrow: Nature and People in the Scottish Highlands |date=3 July 2014 |publisher=Birlinn |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=hZy8BQAAQBAJ&pg=PT66 |accessdate=15 January 2017 }}</ref>
==See also== * [[Canadian Gaelic#Reasons for decline|Canadian Gaelic § Reasons for decline]] * {{lang|oc|[[Vergonha]]}} in [[Occitan]]-speaking France * [[Treachery of the Blue Books]] in Wales * [[American Indian boarding schools]] * [[Canadian Indian residential school system]] * Specific devices for punishing children using the "wrong" language in schools: ** [[Welsh Not]] ** {{lang|fr|[[Symbole]]}} in France ** [[Dialect card]] ({{lang|ja|方言札}}, {{lang|ja-Latn|hōgen fuda}}) in Japan
==References== {{Reflist}}
{{Scottish education}} {{Nineteenth-century Scotland}}
[[Category:1872 in education]] [[Category:1872 in Scotland|Education]] [[Category:History of education in Scotland]] [[Category:Language law]] [[Category:United Kingdom Education Acts]] [[Category:Scottish Gaelic education]] [[Category:United Kingdom Acts of Parliament by year|1872]] [[Category:Acts of the Parliament of the United Kingdom concerning Scotland]]

Monsignor '''Felix Newton Pitt''' was born in 1894. He was born in [[Fairfield, Kentucky]]. He attended the [[St. Meinrad]] Seminary in Indiana from 1911 to 1915. He held a Swiss academic doctorate. One of his achievements was founding and organizing the Catholic school office in [[Louisville, Kentucky]]. In 1928 and 1929 while Secretary of the Catholic School Board he formed the Catholic Recreation Commission. He was a pioneer on WHAS radio in ecumenical broadcast. He has also served on the post-World War II international committee. In 1949 when he was 55 years old he founded Pitt Academy a school for special kids. It was the first facility in Louisville for developmentally disabled students. Msgr. Pitt is also an [[author]] who in 1951 wrote the book "Catholic Education Today and Tomorrow". He died in 1971 at the age of 77.
A biography was published in 2016 by his nephew on his sister's side, Pitt G. Thome: Journey of a Country Soul: The Life and Ministry of Monsignor Felix N. Pitt, Kentucky's Preeminent Catholic Educator of the 20th Century. While it contains personal anecdotes, much of the book focuses on researched historical information placed in the context of events as they occurred.
==See also== *[[List of people from the Louisville metropolitan area]] *[[Pitt Academy]]
==External links== *http://www.archlou.org/archlou/_home/article-1999927184.htm *http://www.pitt.com/ *http://philtar.ucsm.ac.uk/research/red/4957.html
{{DEFAULTSORT:Pitt, Felix Newton}} [[Category:1894 births]] [[Category:1971 deaths]] [[Category:People from Nelson County, Kentucky]] [[Category:Religious leaders from Louisville, Kentucky]] [[Category:Special education]]

revision.comment: removed [[Category:International non-profit organizations]]; added [[Category:Charities based in California]] using [[WP:HC|HotCat]]
revision.text:
'''Global Heritage Fund''' ('''GHF''') is a [[non-profit organization]] that operates internationally. Founded in [[California, United States|California]] in 2002, GHF says it has since then invested over $25 million and secured $20 million in co-funding for 19 global heritage sites to ensure their sustainable preservation and responsible development.<ref name=PRGHF>{{cite web|title=Global Heritage Fund Releases New Report Featuring 10 of Asia’s Most Endangered Cultural Heritage Sites|url=https://finance.yahoo.com/news/global-heritage-fund-releases-report-201400502.html|publisher=[[Yahoo]]! Finance|accessdate=23 June 2012|author=Global Heritage Fund|date=13 May 2012}}</ref> ==GHF projects== Projects are selected by GHF's Senior Advisory Board. GHF states that selection is based on a number of factors, including cultural significance of site, need of country or region in question, and high potential for sustainable preservation through community involvement.<ref name=GHFSelection>{{cite web|title=Project Selection|url=http://globalheritagefund.org/our_approach/project_investigation_and_selection|publisher=Global Heritage Fund|accessdate=22 June 2012}}</ref>
===Current projects=== Based on information from their website, GHF has 13 currently active projects:<ref name=GHFProjects>{{cite web|title=Current Projects|url=http://globalheritagefund.org/index.php/what_we_do/overview/current_projects|publisher=Global Heritage Fund|accessdate=22 June 2012}}</ref> * [[Banteay Chhmar]], [[Cambodia]] * [[Chavín de Huántar|Chavín de Huántar*]], [[Peru]] * [[Ciudad Perdida]], [[Colombia]] * [[Cyrene, Libya|Cyrene*]], [[Libya]] * [[Fujian Tulou|Fujian Tulous*]], [[China]] * [[Göbekli Tepe]], [[Turkey]] * [[Hampi|Hampi*]], [[India]] * [[Rakhigarhi]], [[India]] * [[Marcahuamachuco]], [[Peru]] * [[El Mirador|Mirador]], [[Guatemala]] * [[Pingyao|Pingyao*]], [[China]] * [[Ur]], [[Iraq]] * [[Wat Phu|Wat Phu*]], [[Laos]] (* indicates a [[UNESCO]] [[UNESCO World Heritage Site|World Heritage Site]])
===Completed projects=== GHF has ended its work on six sites: * [[Çatalhöyük]], [[Turkey]] * [[Foguang Temple|Foguang Temple*]], [[China]] * [[Izborsk]], [[Russia]] * [[Kars]], [[Turkey]] * [[Lijiang, Old Town of|Lijiang*]], [[China]] * [[My Son|My Son*]], [[Vietnam]]
(* indicates a UNESCO World Heritage Site)
==Recent initiatives==
===Global Heritage Network=== In 2010, GHF launched [[Global Heritage Network|Global Heritage Network (GHN)]], an early warning and threats monitoring system that uses satellite imaging technology and ground reporting to enable international experts and local conservation leaders to clearly identify and solve imminent threats within the legal core and protected areas of each site.<ref name=GHFnetwork>{{cite web|title=Global Heritage Network (GHN): Threat Monitoring and Collaborative Solutions for Cultural Heritage Sites in the Developing World|url=http://globalheritagefund.org/gh_network/|publisher=Global Heritage Fund|accessdate=22 June 2012}}</ref>
===''Saving Our Vanishing Heritage''=== In October 2010, GHF produced a report titled ''[[Saving Our Vanishing Heritage|Saving Our Vanishing Heritage: Safeguarding Endangered Cultural Heritage Sites in the Developing World]].''<ref name="GHF intro">{{cite web|title=Saving Our Vanishing Heritage |url=http://globalheritagefund.org/what_we_do/introduction |publisher=Global Heritage Fund |accessdate=22 June 2012 |author=Jeff Morgan |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120705231526/http://globalheritagefund.org/what_we_do/introduction |archivedate=5 July 2012 |df= }}</ref> The report listed 500 major archaeological and heritage sites in developing countries, evaluating their current loss and destruction, conservation and development.<ref>{{cite news|title=Report: Ancient ruins worldwide 'on verge of vanishing'|url=http://www.cnn.com/2010/WORLD/meast/10/18/vanishing.historic.sites/|accessdate=22 June 2012|date=18 October 2010|author=Mark Tutton|agency=[[CNN]]}}</ref> It identified nearly 200 of these sites as <nowiki>"At Risk”</nowiki> or <nowiki>“Under Threat,” and 12 as “On the Verge”</nowiki> of irreparable loss and destruction.<ref name=WSJ-vanishing>{{cite news|title=The World's Vanishing History|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052702304510704575561460705107040|accessdate=22 June 2012|newspaper=[[The Wall Street Journal]]|date=21 October 2010|author=Jason Chow}}</ref> The ''Vanishing'' report stated that there were five accelerating man-made threats facing global heritage sites in developing countries: development pressures, unsustainable tourism, insufficient management, looting, and war and conflict.
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * {{official website|http://globalheritagefund.org/}}
[[Category:Heritage organizations]] [[Category:Historic preservation]] [[Category:Archaeological organisations]] [[Category:Charities based in California]]

revision.comment: removed [[Category:Social work organizations]]; added [[Category:Social work organizations in the United States]] using [[WP:HC|HotCat]]
revision.text:
{{multiple issues | {{Third-party|date=July 2017}} {{COI|date=July 2017}} {{notability|date=July 2017}} {{cleanup|reason=excessive citations need to be removed, leaving only the most pertinent|date=August 2017}} }} {{Infobox organization | image =File:Grand Challenges for Social Work logo.jpg | logo = | motto = Social progress powered by science | formation = 2012 | headquarters = University of Maryland, School of Social Work | leader_name = | board_of_directors = | key_people = | parent_organization = American Academy of Social Work and Social Welfare | name = | logo_size = | founding_location = | website = {{URL|www.grandchallengesforsocialwork.org}} | staff = }}
The '''[[Grand Challenges]] for Social Work''' is an initiative spearheaded by the [[American Academy of Social Work and Social Welfare]].
The [[social work]] profession has identified 12 challenges as inspirational objectives for society in the [[United States]]. The challenges are modeled after a similar undertaking led by the [[National Academy of Engineering]].<ref>Kalil, T. (2012, April 12). The Grand Challenges of the 21st century. Speech presented at the Information Technology and Innovation Foundation, Washington, DC. Retrieved from http://www.whitehouse.gov/sites/default/files/microsites/ostp/grandchallenges-speech-04122012.pdf</ref><ref>{{cite journal|date=2013|title=Grand Challenges for Social Work|url=http://www.journals.uchicago.edu/doi/10.5243/jsswr.2013.11|journal=Journal of the Society for Social Work and Research (2013):|volume=4| issue = 3|pages=165–170.|doi=|via=University of Chicago Press Journals|last1=Uehara, et al.|first1=Edwina}}</ref> Dean Edwina Uehara, PhD, Professor and Ballmer Endowed Dean, [[University of Washington School of Social Work|University of Washington, School of Social Work]], proposed the Grand Challenges approach to the American Academy of Social Work and Social Welfare.
Challenges were identified in partnership with sister organizations, including: [[National Association of Social Workers]], [[Council on Social Work Education]],<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.socialworker.com/extras/social-work-month-project-2016/grand-challenges-for-social-work-initiative-and-our-future/|title=The Grand Challenges for Social Work Initiative and Our Future|last=Coffey|first=Darla|date=March 2016|work=The New Social Worker Magazine|access-date=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}}</ref> Society for Social Work and Research, Group for the Advancement of Doctoral Education in Social Work, National Association of Deans and Directors in Social Work, and the St. Louis Group. The 12 Grand Challenges were announced in January 2016 at the Society for Social Work and Research annual conference in Washington, DC.,<ref name=":1">{{Cite news|url=http://www.marketwired.com/press-release/-2088068.htm|title=American Academy of Social Work and Social Welfare|last=|first=|date=January 14, 2016|work=Market Wired Press Release|access-date=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}}</ref><ref>https://www.socialworkers.org/pubs/news/2016/03/social-work-grand-challenges.asp?back=yes</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.umaryland.edu/news/archived-news/january-2016/newspressreleaseshottopics/ssw-plays-role-in-grand--challenges-for-social-work.php|title=SSW Plays Role in Grand Challenges for Social Work|last=Fanning|first=Patricia|date=January 15, 2016|work=University of Maryland Baltimore, Press Release|access-date=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}}</ref> as a public call to action for all professions to work together to create a more just, equitable, and vital society.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=oKbj3y-LUbw|title=Grand Challenges for Social Work Video|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>
In 2013, the Grand Challenges for Social Work Executive Committee engaged national social work organizations, interest groups, and academic institutions to conceptualize and outline the Grand Challenges initiative. The committee decided on an inclusive, bottom-up approach, soliciting ideas from academia, the practice community, and the public. More than 80 suggestions for Grand Challenge topics were submitted online and in-person. From the ideas, the committee issued a call for concept papers and approximately 40 papers were submitted. As part of this work, the group commissioned several background papers<ref>Sherraden, M., Barth, R. P., Brekke, J., Fraser, M., Mandersheid, R., & Padgett, D. (2014). [http://aaswsw.org/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/WP1-with-cover.pdf Social is fundamental:Introduction and context for grand challenges for social work](Grand Challenges for Social Work Initiative Working Paper No. 1). Baltimore, MD:American Academy of Social Work and Social Welfare.</ref><ref name=":0">Sherraden, M., Stuart, P., Barth, R. P., Kemp, S., Lubben, J., Hawkins, J.D., Coulton, C., McRoy, R., Walters, K., Healy, L., Angell, B., Mahoney, K., Brekke, J., Padilla, Y., DiNitto, D., Padgett, D., Schroepfer, T., & Catalano, R., (2014).[http://aaswsw.org/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/WP2-with-cover.pdf Grand accomplishments in social work](Grand Challenges for Social Work Initiative Working Paper No. 2). Baltimore, MD: American Academy of Social Work and Social Welfare.</ref><ref>Uehara, E.S., Barth, R.P., Olson, S., Catalano, R.F., Hawkins, J.D., Kemp, S., Nurius, P.S., Padgett, D.K., & Sherraden, M. (2014). [http://aaswsw.org/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/WP3-with-cover.pdf Identifying and tackling grand challenges for social work] (Grand Challenges for Social Work Initiative Working Paper No. 3). Baltimore, MD: American Academy of Social Work and Social Welfare.</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Barth|first=Richard P.|last2=Gilmore|first2=Grover C.|last3=Flynn|first3=Marilyn S.|last4=Fraser|first4=Mark W.|last5=Brekke|first5=John S.|date=2014-03-18|title=The American Academy of Social Work and Social Welfare|url=http://journals.sagepub.com/doi/10.1177/1049731514527801|journal=Research on Social Work Practice|language=en|volume=24|issue=4|pages=495–500|doi=10.1177/1049731514527801}}</ref> and an Impact Model to define the issues, describe the accomplishments of social work to date, and explain the Grand Challenges concept.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Uehara|first=Edwina|last2=Flynn|first2=Marilyn|last3=Fong|first3=Rowena|last4=Brekke|first4=John|last5=Barth|first5=Richard P.|last6=Coulton|first6=Claudia|last7=Davis|first7=King|last8=DiNitto|first8=Diana|last9=Hawkins|first9=J. == Founding executive committee ==
The founding executive committee was composed of scientists, educators, and policy experts from throughout the field of social work and social welfare. Founding members included: John Brekke, PhD (Co-Chair), [[University of Southern California School of Social Work|School of Social Work, University of Southern California]]; Rowena Fong, EdD (Co-Chair), [[University of Texas at Austin School of Social Work|School of Social Work, The University of Texas at Austin]]; Richard Barth, PhD, MSW, [[University of Maryland School of Social Work|School of Social Work, University of Maryland]]; Claudia Coulton, PhD, Mandel School of Applied Social Sciences, Case Western Reserve University; Diana DiNitto, PhD, [[University of Texas at Austin School of Social Work|School of Social Work, University of Texas at Austin]]; Marilyn Flynn, PhD, School of Social Work, University of Southern California; J. David Hawkins, PhD, [[University of Washington School of Social Work|University of Washington]]; James Lubben, PhD, [[Boston College School of Social Work|School of Social Work, Boston College]]; Ron Mandersheid, PhD, National Association of County Behavioral Health & Developmental Disabilities Directors; Yolanda C. Padilla, PhD, LMSW-AP, [[University of Texas at Austin School of Social Work|School of Social Work, The University of Texas at Austin]]; Michael Sherraden, PhD, [[George Warren Brown School of Social Work]], Washington University of St. Louis; Edwina Uehara, PhD, [[University of Washington School of Social Work|School of Social Work, University of Washington]]; Karina Walters, PhD, School of Social Work, [[University of Washington School of Social Work|University of Washington]]; James Herbert Williams, PhD, Graduate School of Social Work, [[University of Denver]]; Sarah Christa Butts, MSW, first AASWSW Administrator, and Executive Director, [[University of Maryland School of Social Work|University of Maryland, School of Social Work]].
== Executive committee ==
The current executive committee is co-chaired by Marilyn Flynn, PhD, Dean, [[2U (company)|2U]] Endowed Chair in Educational Innovation and Social Work; [[University of Southern California School of Social Work|Suzanne Dworak-Peck, School of Social Work, University of Southern California]]; Michael Sherraden, PhD, George Warren Brown Distinguished University Professor, [[Washington University in St Louis]], [[George Warren Brown School of Social Work]]; and Edwina Uehara, PhD, Professor and [[Steve Ballmer|Ballmer]] Endowed Dean, [[University of Washington School of Social Work]].
== Grand Challenges == The 12 Grand Challenges for Social Work are:
* Ensure healthy development for all youth:<ref>DeVylder, J. E. (2015). [http://aaswsw.org/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/WP6-with-cover.pdf Prevention of schizophrenia and severe mental illness] (Grand Challenges for Social Work Initiative Working Paper No. 6). Cleveland, OH: American Academy of Social Work and Social Welfare.</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=DeVylder|first=Jordan|date=2016|title=Preventing Schizophrenia and Severe Mental Illness: A Grand Challenge for Social Work|url=http://journals.sagepub.com/doi/pdf/10.1177/1049731515622687|journal=Preventing Schizophrenia and Severe Mental Illness: A Grand Challenge for Social Work|volume=26 |issue=4|pages=449–459|via=}}</ref><ref>Hawkins, J. D., Jenson, J. M., Catalano, R. F., Fraser, M. W., Botvin, G. J., Shapiro, V., … the Coalition for Behavioral Health. (2015). [http://aaswsw.org/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/WP10-with-cover.pdf Unleashing the power of prevention] (Grand Challenge for Social Work Initiative Working Paper No. 10). Cleveland, OH: American Academy of Social Work and Social Welfare</ref><ref>Hawkins, J. D., J. M. Jenson, R. Catalano, M. W. Fraser, G. J. Botvin, V. Shapiro, C. H. Brown, W. Beardslee, D. Brent, L. K. Leslie, M. J. Rotheram-Borus, P. Shea, A. Shih, E. Anthony, K. P. Haggerty, K. Bender, D. Gorman-Smith, E. Casey, and S. Stone. 2015. [https://nam.edu/perspectives-2015-unleashing-the-power-of-prevention/ Unleashing the Power of Prevention.] Discussion Paper, Institute of Medicine and National Research Council, Washington, DC</ref> Addressing behavioral health issues in youth is part of this Grand Challenge. Drew Reynolds, a PhD candidate at the Boston College School of Social Work, ties into it with his work on social network analysis and its potential to tackle social problems.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://bcsocialworkblog.com/2015/12/16/bcssw-phd-candidate-tackles-the-grand-challenges-through-social-network-research/|title=BCSSW PhD Candidate Tackles the Grand Challenges through Social Network Research|last=Andrew Reynolds says|date=2015-12-16|website=Innovate@BCSocialWork|access-date=2017-07-28}}</ref> * Close the health gap:<ref>Begun, A. L., Clapp, J. D., & The Alcohol Misuse Grand Challenge Collective. (2015). [http://aaswsw.org/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/WP14-with-cover.pdf Preventing and reducing alcohol misuse and its consequences: A grand challenge for social work] (Grand Challenges for Social Work Initiative Working Paper No. 14). Cleveland, OH: American Academy of Social Work and Social Welfare.</ref><ref>Walters, K. L., Spencer, M. S., Smukler, M., Allen, H. L., Andrews, C., Browne, T., … Uehara, E. (2016). [http://aaswsw.org/wp-content/uploads/2016/01/WP19-with-cover2.pdf Health equity: Eradicating health inequalities for future generations] (Grand Challenges forSocial Work Initiative Working Paper No. 19). Cleveland, OH: American Academy of Social Work and Social Welfare.</ref> In December 2016, the International Journal of Social Work published the paper “Social Work Grand Challenges and the U.N. Sustainable Development Goals: Linking Social Work and Women’s Health.” The authors make the case for “a call to action for more scholarly work on women’s health in the context of current national and global conversations about this social justice issue.”<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.researchgate.net/publication/312273018_Social_Work_Grand_Challenges_and_the_UN_Sustainable_Development_Goals_Linking_Social_Work_and_Women's_Health|title=Social Work Grand Challenges and the U.N. Sustainable Development Goals: Linking Social Work and Women’s Health (PDF Download Available)|website=ResearchGate|language=en|access-date=2017-07-28}}</ref> * Stop family violence.<ref>Edleson, J. L, Lindhorst, T., & Kanuha, V. K. (2015). [http://aaswsw.org/wp-content/uploads/2016/01/WP15.pdf Ending Gender-Based Violence: A Grand Challenge for Social Work] (Grand Challenges for Social Work Initiative Working Paper No. 15). Cleveland, OH: American Academy of Social Work and Social Welfare.</ref><ref>Barth, R. P., Putnam-Hornstein, E., Shaw, T. V., & Dickinson, N. S. (2015). [http://aaswsw.org/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/WP17-with-cover.pdf Safe children: Reducing severe and fatal maltreatment] (Grand Challenges for Social Work Initiative Working Paper No. 17). Cleveland, OH: American Academy of Social Work and Social Welfare.</ref> This grand challenge includes a concerted effort to better integrate the scholarship and practice that links child maltreatment prevention and services with those addressing intimate partner violence. These sub-fields have developed with different methodological and conceptual approaches. The US CDC has recently been promoting the idea of "connecting the dots" which shows that there is quite a bit of continuity between child maltreatment, youth violence, and intimate partner violence, and gender based violence.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Preventing multiple forms of violence: A strategic vision for connecting the dots|last=Center for Disease Control and Prevention|first=|publisher=Atlanta, GA: Division of Violence Prevention, National Center for Injury Prevention and Control, Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.|year=2016|isbn=|location=https://www.cdc.gov/violenceprevention/pdf/strategic_vision.pdf|pages=4–12}}</ref> A recent chapter on this grand challenge by Barth and Macy begins to draw out some of these continuities.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Grand Challenges for Social Work|last=Barth|first=Richard|last2=Macy|first2=Rebecca|publisher=NewYork: Oxford and NASW Press|year=|isbn=|location=|pages=|chapter=Grand challenge of Ending Family Violence}}</ref> * Advance long and productive lives<ref>Morrow-Howell, N., Gonzales, E., Matz-Costa, C., Greenfield, E. A. (2015). [http://aaswsw.org/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/WP8-with-cover.pdf Increasing productive engagement in later life] (Grand Challenges for Social Work Initiative Working Paper No. 8). Cleveland, OH: American Academy of Social Work and Social Welfare.</ref> * Eradicate social isolation:<ref>Lubben, J., Gironda, M., Sabbath, E. Kong, J., & Johnson, C. (2015). [http://aaswsw.org/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/WP7-with-cover.pdf Social isolation presents a grand challenge for social work] (Grand Challenges for Social Work Initiative Working Paper No. 7). Cleveland, OH: American Academy of Social Work and Social Welfare.</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://socialworkers.org/pubs/news/2016/06/isolation-critical-social-problem.asp|title=Isolation seen as critical social problem|last=Laurio|first=Alison|date=June 2016|work=NASW News|access-date=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}}</ref> Social isolation is a growing issue, affecting people of all walks of life and ability. It can affect children and youth, people with disabilities, older people, and people without access to technology. Social workers are on the front lines, addressing these issues in a variety of settings and with a range of interventions, as noted in a piece in the June 2016 issue of NASW News.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://socialworkers.org/pubs/news/2016/06/isolation-critical-social-problem.asp|title=Isolation seen as critical social problem|website=socialworkers.org|access-date=2017-07-28}}</ref> * End homelessness<ref>Henwood, B. F., Wenzel, S., Mangano, P. F., Hombs, M., Padgett, D., Byrne, T., … Uretsky, M. (2015). [http://aaswsw.org/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/WP9-with-cover.pdf The grand challenge of ending homelessness] (Grand Challenges for Social Work Initiative Working Paper No. 9). Cleveland, OH: American Academy of Social Work and Social Welfare.</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Larkin|first=Heather|last2=Henwood|first2=Benjamin|last3=Fogel|first3=Sondra J.|last4=Aykanian|first4=Amanda|last5=Briar-Lawson|first5=Katharine H.|last6=Donaldson|first6=Linda Plitt|last7=Herman|first7=Daniel|last8=Little|first8=Samuel B.|last9=Meyer-Adams|first9=Nancy|date=2016-09-08|title=Responding to the Grand Challenge to End Homelessness: The National Homelessness Social Work Initiative|url=https://doi.org/10.1606/1044-3894.2016.97.31|journal=Families in Society: The Journal of Contemporary Social Services|language=EN|volume=97|issue=3|pages=153–159|doi=10.1606/1044-3894.2016.97.31}}</ref> * Create social responses to a changing environment<ref>Kemp, S. Cleveland, OH: American Academy of Social Work and Social Welfare.</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://msass.case.edu/grand-challenges-for-social-work-identify-top-social-problems-coulton-moderates-challenge-on-technology/|title="Grand Challenges for Social Work" Identify Top Social Problems; Coulton Moderates Challenge on Technology|last=|first=|date=|website=Case Western Reserve University, Jack, Joseph, and Morton Mandel School of Applied Social Sciences.|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> Kristin Battista-Frazee, MSW, explores the ways that technology is used in social work—from educating students and communicating via social media to online counseling and electronic records.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.socialworktoday.com/archive/011917p10.shtml|title=The High-Tech Social Worker -- Myth or Reality?|last=Inc.|first=Great Valley Publishing Company,|website=www.socialworktoday.com|language=en|access-date=2017-07-28}}</ref> Jonathan Singer, PhD, LCSW, of Loyola University School of Social Work, wrote a blog post on a paper he co-authored calling for practice innovation through technology in the field of social work.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.husita.org/grand-challenge/|title=Thoughts on the Grand Challenges paper: "Practice Innovation through Technology in the Digital Age: A Grand Challenge for Social Work"|date=2016-02-17|access-date=2017-07-28|language=en-US}}</ref> * Promote smart decarceration:<ref>Pettus-Davis, C., & Epperson, M. L., & Sherraden, M. (2015). [http://aaswsw.org/wp-content/uploads/2016/01/WP16-with-cover-2.pdf Reversing extreme inequality] (Grand Challenges for Social Work Initiative Working Paper No. 16). == Activities == Social work scholars are leading 12 implementation networks, and universities of all sizes are beginning to organize by regional consortia. There have been Grand Challenge-themed meetings and conferences,<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://csd.wustl.edu/events/ConferencesAndSymposia/Pages/Grand-Challenges-for-Social-Work-Policy-Conference.aspx|title=Social Innovation for America's Renewal: Ideas, Evidence, Action, Washington University in St Louis|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> colloquia,<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://socialwelfare.berkeley.edu/newsarticles/grand-challenges-social-work|title=Grand Challenges in Social Work, Colloquia series focuses on challenges ahead for the profession|last=|first=|date=|website=Berkeley Social Welfare|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> as well as several special issue journals.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.journals.uchicago.edu/pb-assets/docs/journals/JSSWR_CFP_2017.pdf|title=Announcement of Special Issue, Call for Papers, Ensure Healthy Development of All Youth Through the Power of Prevention|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> Curriculum development and recruitment of students is also a significant goal. In 2016, USC School of Social Work announced a DSW program themed around the Grand Challenges.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://sowkweb.usc.edu/news/new-online-doctor-social-work-application-now-available|title=USC Suzanne Dworak Peck School of Social Work|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> Additionally, each Grand Challenge has developed a set of policy recommendations.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://csd.wustl.edu/events/ConferencesAndSymposia/Pages/Grand-Challenges-Policy-Briefs.aspx|title=Washington University in St Louis, Center for Social Development|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> The [[University of Maryland School of Social Work]] published an article detailing the history and progress of the Grand Challenges initiative in the Winter 2017 issue of Connections Magazine.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.ssw.umaryland.edu/media/ssw/connections/Connections_Winter2017_Feb7-lo-res.pdf|title=Grand Challenges for Social Work: Achieving Measurable Progress for Society Through Social Work and Science|last=|first=|date=|work=Connections Magazine, University of Maryland, School of Social Work|access-date=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|pages 18-33=}}</ref>
In 2017, the Journal of the Society for Social Work and Research published a special section on implementing the Grand Challenges.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Jenson|first1=Jeffrey|title=Special Section: Implementing the Grand Challenges for Social Work Initiative A Note From the Editor-in-Chief|url=http://www.journals.uchicago.edu/doi/full/10.1086/690618|website=Journal of the Society for Social Work and Research}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Uehara|first=Edwina S.|last2=Barth|first2=Richard P.|last3=Coffey|first3=Darla|last4=Padilla|first4=Yolanda|last5=McClain|first5=Angelo|date=2017-01-23|title=An Introduction to the Special Section on Grand Challenges for Social Work|url=http://www.journals.uchicago.edu/doi/10.1086/690563|journal=Journal of the Society for Social Work and Research|volume=8|issue=1|pages=75–85|doi=10.1086/690563|issn=2334-2315}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Nurius|first=Paula S.|last2=Coffey|first2=Darla Spence|last3=Fong|first3=Rowena|last4=Korr|first4=Wynne Sandra|last5=McRoy|first5=Ruth|date=2017-01-24|title=Preparing Professional Degree Students to Tackle Grand Challenges: A Framework for Aligning Social Work Curricula|url=http://www.journals.uchicago.edu/doi/10.1086/690562|journal=Journal of the Society for Social Work and Research|volume=8|issue=1|pages=99–118|doi=10.1086/690562|issn=2334-2315}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Gehlert|first=Sarah|last2=Hall|first2=Kara L.|last3=Palinkas|first3=Lawrence A.|date=2017-01-25|title=Preparing Our Next-Generation Scientific Workforce to Address the Grand Challenges for Social Work|url=http://www.journals.uchicago.edu/doi/10.1086/690659|journal=Journal of the Society for Social Work and Research|volume=8|issue=1|pages=119–136|doi=10.1086/690659|issn=2334-2315}}</ref> There are also a series of books on the 12 challenge topics.<ref>R. Fong, J. Lubben, & R. P. Barth (Eds).  (in press). Grand Challenges for Social Work and Society. Washington, DC and New York:  NASW and Oxford University Presses. </ref><ref>{{Cite book|url=https://global.oup.com/academic/product/housing-first-9780199989805?cc=us&lang=en&|title=Housing First: Ending Homelessness, Transforming Systems, and Changing Lives|date=2015-11-03|publisher=Oxford University Press|isbn=978-0-19-998980-5|location=Oxford, New York}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|url=https://global.oup.com/academic/product/smart-decarceration-9780190653095?q=smart%20decarceration&lang=en&cc=us|title=Smart Decarceration: Achieving Criminal Justice Transformation in the 21st Century|publisher=Oxford University Press|isbn=978-0-19-065309-5|location=Oxford, New York}}</ref>
== University efforts == Several events focused on Grand Challenges are taking place around the country. Berkeley Social Welfare has held sessions on health and mental health, the effect of new technology on [[Social services|social service]] delivery and outcomes, women and poverty, and issues around aging services and policy.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://socialwelfare.berkeley.edu/newsarticles/grand-challenges-social-work|title=Grand Challenges in Social Work {{!}} Berkeley Social Welfare|website=socialwelfare.berkeley.edu|language=en|access-date=2017-07-28}}</ref>
On November 11, 2016, the University of Iowa, with the support of the National Association of Social Workers, held a day-long conference on the Grand Challenges. The aim of the conference was to bolster the leadership capacity of social work professionals and social justice advocates by detailing the issues and current efforts to address them, as well as initiating conversations around promising new approaches.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://clas.uiowa.edu/socialwork/sites/clas.uiowa.edu.socialwork/files/FINAL.pdf|title=University of Iowa Conference on Grand Challenges|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>
== Innovations == Social work has been concerned with social policy innovation for some time. The profession has been a leader in freeing families from poor houses and children from orphanages, halting [[Child labour|child labor]], advocating for [[Women's rights|women’s rights]] and [[civil rights]], creating [[Social Security (United States)|Social Security]] and [[Fair Labor Standards Act|fair labor standards]], fighting for fair and inclusive [[housing (residential)|housing]], and much more.<ref name=":0" /> The social-justice values of social work, combined with research and evidence to inform policy, have made these contributions possible. The profession continues this social policy mission and leadership with the Grand Challenges initiative. In September 2016, the [[George Warren Brown School of Social Work|Brown School of Social Work at Washington University in St. Louis]] hosted a Grand Challenges Policy Conference in partnership with the AASWSW to specify steps toward positive policy action. Each of the 12 grand challenge networks have developed a set of policy recommendations.<ref>Berzin, S. C., Coulton, C. J., Goerge, R., Hitchcock, L., Putnam-Hornstein, E., Sage, M., & Singer, J. (2016, September). ''[https://csd.wustl.edu/Publications/Documents/PB8.pdf Policy recommendations for meeting the Grand Challenge to Harness Technology for Social Good]'' (Grand Challenges for Social Work Initiative Policy Brief No. 8). Cleveland, OH: American Academy of Social Work & Social Welfare.</ref><ref>Brown, S., Casey, E. A., Crewe, S. E., Gironda, M., Johnson, C., Lubben, J., … Tracy, E. (2016, September). ''[https://csd.wustl.edu/Publications/Documents/PB5.pdf Policy recommendations for meeting the Grand Challenge to Eradicate Social Isolation]'' (Grand Challenges for Social Work Initiative Policy Brief No. 5). Cleveland, OH: American Academy of Social Work & Social Welfare.</ref><ref>Elliott, W., III, Henly, J. R., Lambert, S. J., Lein, L., Romich, J. L., Shanks, T. R., & Sherraden, M. (2016, September). ''[https://csd.wustl.edu/Publications/Documents/PB10.pdf Policy recommendations for meeting the Grand Challenge to Reduce Extreme Economic Inequality]'' (Grand Challenges for Social Work Initiative Policy Brief No. 10). Cleveland, OH: American Academy of Social Work & Social Welfare.</ref><ref>Epperson, M., & Pettus-Davis, C. (2016, September). ''[https://csd.wustl.edu/Publications/Documents/PB9.pdf Policy recommendations for meeting the Grand Challenge to Promote Smart Decarceration]'' (Grand Challenges for Social Work Initiative Policy Brief No. 9). Cleveland, OH: American Academy of Social Work & Social Welfare.</ref><ref>Hawkins, J. D., Jenson, J. M., DeVylder, J., Catalano, R. F., Botvin, G. J., Fraser, M., … Bumbarger, B. (2016, September). ''[https://csd.wustl.edu/Publications/Documents/PB1.pdf Policy recommendations for meeting the Grand Challenge to Ensure Healthy Development for All Youth]'' (Grand Challenges for Social Work Initiative Policy Brief No. 1). Cleveland, OH: American Academy of Social Work & Social Welfare.</ref><ref>Huang, J., Sherraden, M. S., Clancy, M. M., Sherraden, M., Birkenmaier, J., Despard, M., … Rothwell, D. (2016, September). ''[https://csd.wustl.edu/Publications/Documents/PB11.pdf Policy recommendations for meeting the Grand Challenge to Build Financial Capability and Assets for All]'' (Grand Challenges for Social Work Initiative Policy Brief No. 11). Cleveland, OH: American Academy of Social Work & Social Welfare.</ref><ref>Kemp, S. P., Mason, L. R., Palinkas, L. A., Rechkemmer, A., & Teixeira, S. (2016, September). ''[https://csd.wustl.edu/Publications/Documents/PB7.pdf Policy recommendations for meeting the Grand Challenge to Create Social Responses to a Changing Environment]'' (Grand Challenges for Social Work Initiative Policy Brief No. 7). Cleveland, OH: American Academy of Social Work & Social Welfare.</ref><ref>Kulkarni, S. J., Barth, R. P., & Messing, J. T. (2016, September). ''[https://csd.wustl.edu/Publications/Documents/PB3.pdf Policy recommendations for meeting the Grand Challenge to Stop Family Violence]'' (Grand Challenges for Social Work Initiative Policy Brief No. 3). Cleveland, OH: American Academy of Social Work & Social Welfare.</ref><ref>McRoy, R. G., Padilla, Y. C., Calvo, R., Goldbach, J. T., & Teasley, M. L. (with Amaro, H., … Waters, M. C.). (2016, September). ''[https://csd.wustl.edu/Publications/Documents/PB12.pdf Policy recommendations for meeting the Grand Challenge to Achieve Equal Opportunity and Justice]'' (Grand Challenges for Social Work Initiative Policy Brief No. 12). Cleveland, OH: American Academy of Social Work & Social Welfare.</ref><ref>Morrow-Howell, N., Gonzales, E., & Matz-Costa, C. (2016, September). ''[https://csd.wustl.edu/Publications/Documents/PB4.pdf Policy recommendations for meeting the Grand Challenge to Advance Long and Productive Lives]'' (Grand Challenges for Social Work Initiative Policy Brief No. 4). Cleveland, OH: American Academy of Social Work & Social Welfare.</ref><ref>Padgett, D. K., Henwood, B. F., & Culhane, D. P. (2016, September). ''[https://csd.wustl.edu/Publications/Documents/PB6.pdf Policy recommendations for meeting the Grand Challenge to End Homelessness]'' (Grand Challenges for Social Work Initiative Policy Brief No. 6). Cleveland, OH: American Academy of Social Work & Social Welfare.</ref><ref>Spencer, M. S., Walters, K. L., & Clapp, J. D. (2016, September). ''[https://csd.wustl.edu/Publications/Documents/PB2.pdf Policy recommendations for meeting the Grand Challenge to Close the Health Gap]'' (Grand Challenges for Social Work Initiative Policy Brief No. 2). Cleveland, OH: American Academy of Social Work & Social Welfare.</ref> These recommendations are now being used to generate and inform policy and civic engagement<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.socialjusticesolutions.org/2017/01/27/social-work-civic-engagement-12-grand-challenges/|title=Social Work, Civic Engagement and the 12 Grand Challenges|last=Lewis|first=Charles|date=|website=Social Justice Solutions|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> at local, state, regional, and national levels.
The Grand Challenges for Social Work offer an interdisciplinary approach to major issues facing our society, on a national level and locally. In Detroit, Tam Perry, PhD, has called for researchers, community members, practitioners, and policymakers to collaborate on making real, sustained changes to benefit the city’s residents.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.authorityhealth.org/-/population-health-blog/uncategorized/social-works-grand-challenges-and-its-relevance-to-health-concerns-in-detroit|title=» Social Work’s Grand Challenges and their relevance to health concerns in Detroit|website=www.authorityhealth.org|language=en-US|access-date=2017-07-28}}</ref>
== Defining the profession == The Grand Challenges initiative is also helping to define social work as a profession. Many people outside the field of social work do not realize the breadth of issues that social workers affect. There have been several efforts to help the public better understand the various roles social workers play.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Teasley|first=M. L.|date=2015-07-01|title=Social Work Grand Challenges: An Opportunity to Increase Student Success|url=https://academic.oup.com/cs/article-abstract/37/3/131/404174/Social-Work-Grand-Challenges-An-Opportunity-to?redirectedFrom=fulltext|journal=Children & Schools|language=en|volume=37|issue=3|pages=131–133|doi=10.1093/cs/cdv019|issn=1532-8759}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.socialworker.com/extras/social-work-month-project-2016/grand-challenges-for-social-work-initiative-and-our-future/|title=The Grand Challenges for Social Work Initiative and Our Future|date=2016-02-29|work=SocialWorker.com|access-date=2017-07-28|language=en-us}}</ref>
The Grand Challenges initiative also provides an opportunity to further define the profession through curriculum changes in schools of social work. The University of Illinois Urbana-Champaign has published a paper that “describes the relevance of the GCSWI to professional education and suggests the collective-impact model as a heuristic for professional preparation to collaborate in grand challenge contexts.”<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://socialwork.illinois.edu/implementing-the-grand-challenges-for-social-work-initiative/|title=Implementing the Grand Challenges for Social Work Initiative – School of Social Work, University of Illinois|website=socialwork.illinois.edu|language=en|access-date=2017-07-28}}</ref>
And the Grand Challenges initiative has already reached beyond the United States. Social workers in the United Kingdom are considering a similar effort as a way forward for the field of social work there.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Baron|first=Sam|last2=McLaughlin|first2=Hugh|title=Grand challenges: a way forward for social work?|url=http://www.tandfonline.com/doi/pdf/10.1080/02615479.2017.1283729|journal=Social Work Education|volume=36|issue=1|pages=1–5|doi=10.1080/02615479.2017.1283729}}</ref>
== References == {{Reflist}}

revision.text:
'''Hazing in Greek letter organizations''' is defined as any act or set of acts that constitutes [[hazing]] and occurs in connection to a [[Fraternities and sororities in North America|fraternity or sorority]]. Hazing is often cited as one of the most harmful aspects of fraternities and sororities and poses a major threat to their existence, drawing great criticism from educators and administrators {{Harv|Whipple|Sullivan|1998}}. As fraternities and sororities are very diverse in their structures, regulations, governing entities, and memberships, and as hazing can take on many forms, the issue of hazing within these organizations is complex and multifaceted. ==Definitions== While most educational institutions include [[hazing]] in their disciplinary procedures, definitions of hazing can vary substantially {{Harv|Hollmann|2002}}. The Fraternal Information & Programming Group (FIPG) defines hazing activities as:{{cite web | title = FIPG Risk Management Policy | publisher = Fraternal Information & Programming Group | date = July 2008 | url = http://www.fipg.org/FIPG/FIPG.nsf/835fe7d91217664d8525723c007a7545/9c0d3c4d4ca5614e8525734b007b08a4/$FILE/FIPG%20Policy%20July%202008.pdf | format = [[Portable Document Format|PDF]] | accessdate = 27 May 2009}}
Any action taken or situation created, intentionally, whether on or off fraternity premises, to produce mental or physical discomfort, embarrassment, harassment, or ridicule. Such activities may include but are not limited to the following: use of alcohol, paddling in any form, creation of excessive fatigue, physical and psychological shocks, quests, treasure hunts, scavenger hunts, road trips or any other such activities carried on outside or inside of the confines of the chapter house; wearing of public apparel which is conspicuous and not normally in good taste, engaging in public stunts and buffoonery, morally degrading or humiliating games and activities, and other activities which are not consistent with academic achievement, fraternal law, ritual or policy or the regulations and policies of the educational institution or applicable state law.
Hazing is a crime in 44 states.{{cite web | title = State Anti-Hazing Laws | work = StopHazing.org: Educating to Eliminate Hazing | url = http://www.stophazing.org/laws.html | accessdate = 26 May 2009 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20090422161349/http://www.stophazing.org/laws.html | archivedate = 22 April 2009 | df = }} For example, the Arizona Revised Statutes provides the following definition:[http://www.azleg.state.az.us/ars/13/03107.htm 15-2301 - Hazing prevention policies; definitions]
"Hazing" means any intentional, knowing or reckless act committed by a student, whether individually or in concert with other persons, against another student, and in which both of the following apply: (a) The act was committed in connection with an initiation into, an affiliation with or the maintenance of membership in any organization that is affiliated with an educational institution. (b) The act contributes to a substantial risk of potential physical injury, mental harm or degradation or causes physical injury, mental harm or personal degradation.
Most educational institutions have their own definitions of hazing, and many are required to by state statutes. Generally, institutions of higher education will have their own definitions of hazing, though they may closely mirror definitions found in their respective state statutes. For example, the [[University of Arizona]] provides the following definition of hazing in its “University of Arizona Hazing Policy”, revised October 25, 2001:{{Cite journal|title=University of Arizona Hazing Policy|url=http://web.arizona.edu/~policy/Hazing.pdf|format=[[Portable Document Format|PDF]]|accessdate=31 May 2009|date=25 October 2001|publisher=University of Arizona Dean of Student’s Office|ref=harv|postscript=.|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100616190132/http://web.arizona.edu/~policy/Hazing.pdf|archivedate=16 June 2010|df=}}
"Hazing" means any intentional, knowing or reckless act committed by a student, whether individually or in concert with other persons, against another student, and in which both of the following apply: (a) The act was committed in connection with an initiation into, an affiliation with or the maintenance of membership in any organization that is affiliated with the University. (b) The act contributes to a substantial risk of potential physical injury, mental harm or degradation or causes physical injury, mental harm or personal degradation.
Note that the University of Arizona’s definition of hazing is virtually identical to the definition outlined in the Arizona Revised Statutes. The current [[North American Interfraternity Conference]] (NIC) definition of hazing also includes anything that could turn into hazing. This is the reason that many potentially innocent activities, such as a scavenger hunt, are included under hazing; they could start out as perfectly legal events, but could easily be modified to include some activity that could make it hazing (ex. stealing some of the items on the list or adding heavy drinking before or during). Requiring candidates, or even members as there is "brother on brother hazing", to attend events or be at a certain place at a certain time is also hazing. Many also consider the use of the term 'pledge' to be hazing. It should also be noted that things like physical activity will be condoned if there are fraters that are in the [[US Army]] or other armed forces present, whereas if those members weren't there it would be considered hazing.(Godwin, 2012) ==Problems in the quantitative analysis== Due to the nature of hazing, the secretive nature of Greek letter organizations, and the fear of negative repercussions, hazing is largely underreported. Most, if not all, hazing activities take place either during pledge (or “interest”) activities or rituals, which are almost always secretive. Additionally, since many Greek letter organizations, such as those governed by the [[National Pan-Hellenic Council]] (NPHC) and the [[National Association of Latino Fraternal Organizations]] (NALFO), prohibit their pledges (also known as “interests” or “new members”) from revealing their association with their organization until they have been initiated, it becomes increasingly difficult for institutions to reach out to members in anti-hazing efforts. It also becomes virtually impossible for these pledges or interests to reach out for help, especially if they wish to remain members, pledges, or interests of their organizations. However, Cheryl Drout and Christie Corsoro of State University of New York at Fredonia state, "Hazing, which is officially banned by all national Greek organizations, frequently comes to the public’s attention through the popular news media when the activities become fatal” (Drout & Corsoro, 2003). Unfortunately for multitudes of members of Greek organizations, “Sororities and fraternities have come to be synonymous with elitism, sexual assault, high-risk hazing (initiation ceremonies) and other bad behavior on American university campuses” (Marcus, 2007). Fraternities and sororities are commonly associated with [[paddle (spanking)|paddling]] of members, especially new members or pledges, as part of their hazing rituals.Smith, Emily E.[http://www.nypost.com/p/news/local/brooklyn/frat_treated_student_to_badly_his_cv2oyewTIJtQF6XdIjNCDK#ixzz1KJ2MySsR "Frat treated student so badly that 'his life may be ruined': suit"]. ''[[New York Post]]'', April 22, 2011. ==Responses to hazing== Many educational institutions have developed anti-hazing programs, which encourage alternatives to hazing through the planning of purposeful activities, inform students of how to take action and avoid being a [[Bystander effect|bystander]], and provide clear consequences for those students and/or organizations who violate hazing policies {{Harv|Hollmann|2002}}. Additionally, hazing has become a central focus of programs designed to help Greek letter organizations become more value congruent through institutionalized standards and expectations {{Harv|Shonrock|1998}}. Attempts at preventing hazing have also targeted Greek letter organizations at the national level. {{Harvtxt|Cobb|McRee|2007}} note the important role of culture change within the North American fraternity and sorority movement and even encourage the closure of chapters that consistently partake in illegal and risky activities and pose threats to their local and university communities. {{Harvtxt|DeSousa|Gordon|Kimbrough|2004}} propose the creation of a recognized pledge program in which national fraternity and sorority leaders participate, under the recognized supervision of university officials, as well as the yearly evaluation of fraternities and sororities to determine their eligibility for continued recognition and sponsorship. Again, such a proposal is difficult since many NPHC and NALFO organizations, not to mention other organizations not governed by these umbrella organizations, keep their pledge, interest, or new member programs completely secretive. Greek letter organizations have themselves taken measures to prevent hazing within their member chapters. As such, individual national organizations have taken various measures to ensure the safety of members with regard to hazing. The [[National Panhellenic Conference]], which governs 26 national and international women’s sororities, includes sanctions against both individuals and groups ranging from member/chapter probation to expulsion of offending members or revocation of the chapter’s charter.{{cite web | title = Frequently Asked Questions About Hazing | publisher = National Panhellenic Council | url = https://www.npcwomen.org/resources/pdf/FAQ-About%20Hazing.pdf | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20140408041425/https://www.npcwomen.org/resources/pdf/FAQ-About%20Hazing.pdf | dead-url = yes | archive-date = 8 April 2014 | format = [[Portable Document Format|PDF]] | accessdate = 16 July 2015 }} The organization also runs an anti-hazing hotline for anonymous incident reporting. Similarly, the North American Interfraternity Conference released a resolution{{cite web | title = NIC Resolutions | publisher = North-American Interfraternity Conference, Inc. | url = http://www.nicindy.org/nic-resolutions1.html | accessdate = 16 July 2015}} condemning the practice. In 2010, NIC CEO and President Peter Smithhisler derided the use of hazing as a means of building comradery:{{cite web | title = Can Hazing Be Stopped? | publisher = Inside Higher Ed | url = https://www.insidehighered.com/news/2010/11/24/hazing | accessdate = 19 July 2015}}
“The intention of the hazer is to create unity, to create trust, to establish a person’s commitment to the organization,” he said. “But in reality, what he is doing is creating a bond among the hazees while eliminating the trust between hazer and hazee, ultimately breaking down the bond of brotherhood.”
Additionally, there are individual national Greek Letter Organizations taking the initiative against activities related to hazing. For example, in 2012{{cite web | title = Phi Beta Sigma General Board Mandates All Chapters Conduct Anti-Hazing Workshops | publisher = Phi Beta Sigma Fraternity, Inc. | url = http://www.phibetasigma1914.org/anti-hazing/ | accessdate = 20 July 2015}} Phi Beta Sigma fraternity adopted an anti-hazing campaign to eradicate hazing practices in its individual chapters, providing numerous support resources to effectively combat the practice. ==Fraternity hazing characteristics== In an article by Hank Nuwer, a professor of journalism and an author of books on hazing, he compared the hazing rituals of fraternities to [[cult]]s. Nuwer talks about the aspects of hazing that make the pledge keep coming back to the fraternity and the ramifications of dropping out. Nuwer consulted with a professor in psychology, [[Margaret Thaler Singer]], to get a better understanding of the characteristics of cults to relate those behaviors with fraternity hazing. Nuwer believes that hazing, along with a cult, is a “’systematic’ manipulation and coercion to effect ‘psychological and social influence’” (Nuwer, B7). The first aspect Nuwer wrote about was “’enforced dependency’” (Nuwer, B7). He talked about how the hazing process where fraternities make their pledges stay at the house the whole time, keeping them sleep deprived and cutting them off from daily activities makes them dependent on their fraternity. Even though the "pledges" may fall behind in school or lose friends outside of their fraternity, the fraternity convinces the pledge that after the hazing ceases, it will all be worth it. This reassurance keeps the pledges coming back, reliant on the people who are hazing them; relating to the next aspect of "family" (Nuwer, B7). Fraternities continually tell their pledges they are joining a family. This aspect appeals to most college freshman that are having a hard time making friends in a different environment. Last, Nuwer discussed how fraternities "make it hard for their members to leave" (Nuwer, B7). He says that those who decide not to join after being hazed have already given up so much for the fraternity that they feel alone and may even experience [[post-traumatic stress]]. Nuwer gives solutions to hazing in fraternities including stronger consequences for those involved in the hazing and that colleges should become more intertwined with the Greek letter community to learn about hazing and to stop it.Nuwer In a {{Harvtxt|Smith|2015}} article on the motivations for hazing, she states that such actions come from a desire to prove a state of "manliness." Hazing practices in fraternity life began to appear shortly after the [[American Civil War |Civil War]]. Veterans brought the hazing practices of their battalions back with them, adopting such activities into fraternity life. The purpose of hazing was perceived as a way of providing young males an outlet to prove their manliness through rites and trials, showing themselves to be men and not boys. Other hazing practices served to put an individual in his place, reducing his sense of personal omnipotence to "subsume his individuality into something larger and better than himself" (Smith, 2015). ==In popular culture== The 1977 film ''[[Fraternity Row (film)|Fraternity Row]]'', set in the 1950s, deals with the subject of hazing at a college fraternity, depicting a number of such practices and culminating with [[Gregory Harrison]] as a victim of a hazing ritual that inadvertently takes a fatal turn. ==Notes== {{reflist|30em}} ==See also== *[[Hazing]] *[[History of North American college fraternities and sororities]] *[[Chuck Stenzel]] *[[Matt's Law]] *[[The Gordie Foundation]] *[[List of hazing deaths in the Philippines]] *[[List of hazing deaths in the United States]] ==References== *{{cite journal | last1 = Cobb | first1 = L. Martin | first2 = Michael | last2 = McRee | title = Why We Should Close More Chapters | series = Spring | journal = Perspectives | volume = 2007 | pages = 4–8 | year = 2007 | ref = harv | postscript = .}} *{{cite book|last1=DeSousa|first1=D. Jason|last2=Michael V.W.|last3=Kimbrough|first3=Walter M.|editor-last=Nuwer|editor-first=Hank|title=The hazing reader|year=2004|publisher=Indiana University Press|location=Bloomington|isbn=0-253-21654-0|pages=106–109|chapter= Pledging and hazing in African-American fraternities and sororities}} *{{cite journal | doi = 10.2224/sbp.2003.31.6.535 | last1 = Drout | first1 = Cheryl | last2 = Corsoro | first2 = Christie | title = Attitudes toward fraternity hazing among fraternity members, sorority members, and non-Greek students | journal = Social Behavior & Personality: an International Journal | volume = 31 | issue = 6 | pages = 535 | year = 2003 | ref = harv | postscript = .}} *{{cite journal | last = Hollmann | first = Barbara B. | title = Organizations | journal = New Directions for Student Services | volume = 1998 | issue = 81 | pages = 79–85 | year = 1998 | doi = 10.1002/ss.8107 | ref = harv | postscript = .}} *{{cite journal | last1 = Whipple | first1 = Edward G. | last2 = Sullivan | first2 = Eileen G. | title = Greek Letter Organizations: Communities of Learners? | journal = New Directions for Student Services | volume = 1998 | issue = 81 | pages = 7–17 | year = 1998 | doi = 10.1002/ss.8101 | ref = harv | postscript = .}} * Thwing, C.F., "College Hazing", ''Scribners Monthly'', Vol.17, No.3, (January 1879), pp. 331–334. *{{cite journal | last = Nuwer | first = Hank | title = Greek Letters Don't Justify Cult-Like Hazing of Pledges | journal = Chronicle of Higher Education | volume = 46 | issue = 14 | pages = B7 | year = 1999 | ref = Nuwer | postscript = .}} *{{cite journal| last = Smith | first = Emily | title = On Fraternities & Manliness | journal = New Criterion | volume = 33 | issue = 9 | pages = 61–63 | year = 2015 | ref = harv | postscript = .}} *{{cite journal| last = Godwin | first = Kimberly A. | title = The Influence of Standards on the College Fraternity Man: An Evaluative Study on the Impact of the 2004 Implementation of the North American Interfraternity Conference Standards for Member Organizations | journal = Academic Search Complete | pages = 210 | year = 2012 | ref = harv | postscript = .}} August 2010}} *{{cite web | title = Anti-Hazing | publisher = Anti-hazing.tripod.com | url = http://anti-hazing.tripod.com/ | accessdate = 31 May 2009 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20040410161905/http://anti-hazing.tripod.com/ | archivedate = 10 April 2004 | df = }} *{{cite book | last = Jones | first = Ricky L. | title = Black haze: violence, sacrifice, and manhood in Black Greek-letter fraternities | publisher = State University of New York Press | year = 2004 | location = Albany, NY | isbn = 978-0-7914-5976-8}} *{{cite book | last = Association of Latino Fraternal Organizations By-Laws | publisher = National Association of Latino Fraternal Organizations | year = 2008 | url = |fix-attempted=yes }} *{{cite web | title = National Association of Latino Fraternal Organizations Shared Standards | publisher = National Association of Latino Fraternal Organizations | year = 2008 | http://www.nphchq.org/docs/NPHCJointPositionStatementAgainstHazing2003.pdf | format = [[Portable Document Format|PDF]] | accessdate = 27 May 2009 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20061212041403/http://www.nphchq.org/docs/NPHCJointPositionStatementAgainstHazing2003.pdf | archivedate = 12 December 2006 | df = }} *{{cite book | editor-last=Nuwer|editor-first=Hank|title=The hazing reader|year=2004|publisher=Indiana University Press|location=Bloomington|isbn=0-253-21654-0}} *{{cite book | editor-last = Parks | editor-first = Gregory S. | title = Black Greek-letter organizations in the twenty-first century | publisher = University Press of Kentucky | year = 2008 | location = Lexington, KY | isbn = 978-0-8131-2491-9}} *{{cite web | title = StopHazing.org — "Educating to Eliminate Hazing" | publisher = StopHazing.org | url = http://www.stophazing.org/ | accessdate = 31 May 2009}} {{Fraternities and Sororities
